documents.content:
In accordance with industry standards, real property and common areas donated by the developer 
are not capitalized on the Association’s financial statements.  Personal property purchased with 
Association funds, to which the Association holds title, will be capitalized at cost and depreciated over 
their estimated useful lives using the straight-line method of depreciation.  Common property consists of,
but is not limited to parks, recreational facilities, community streets, walkways, and parking lots.



7

THE HOMEOWNERS' ASSOCIATION FOR CHANDLER CREEK, INC.
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (CONT.)

DECEMBER 31, 2013

NOTE 2 -- SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES (CONT.)

D. FISCAL YEAR

The Association has a fiscal year beginning on January 1 and ending on December 31.

E. CASH AND CASH EQUIVALENTS

Cash and cash equivalents for the statement of cash flows include amounts in checking accounts.

F. ESTIMATES

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting 
principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of 
assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial 
statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.  Actual 
results could differ from those estimates.

G. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS

Subsequent events were evaluated through September 25, 2014, which is the date the financial 
statements were available to be issued.

NOTE 3 -- FUTURE MAJOR REPAIRS AND REPLACEMENTS

Although not specifically required in by-laws, industry practice is to establish reserves over a 
number of years to fund major repairs and replacement of Common Area components.  Accumulated 
funds for major repairs and replacements should be accounted for in separate certificates of deposit and 
savings accounts and generally are not available for expenditures for normal operations.

CHANDLER CREEK HOA POOL RULES 
Rules/Hours are subject to change 

 
HOURS: 

Regular Season: April 1 to October 31: 7am to 9pm  
Off-season: November 1 to March 31: 7am to 7pm 

 
ONLY RESIDENTS THAT HAVE PAID ALL HOMEOWNER ASSOCIATION ASSESSMENTS WILL BE PERMITTED TO USE THE POOL AND 
TENNIS COURT FACILITIES. 
 

Pool Monitors represent the HOA Board of Directors and have authority to make discretionary rulings on behavior not explicitly 
covered by these and other rules. They are not lifeguards and will not act as such.  Complaints about their rulings should be taken to 
the Association management after first complying with the decision(s) made by the Pool Monitors. Pool Monitors are authorized to 
enforce the following rules including the ejection of non-compliant residents and/or guests. 
 

Any individual(s) reported to be/or found to be in violation of any of these following pool rules will be reported to the Chandler 
Creek Homeowners Association and possibly the Williamson County Sheriff’s Office (as applicable).  The nature of the situation will 
be considered and action(s) toward resolution will be at the Board’s discretion. 
 
1. The Chandler Creek swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OUR RISK pool.  No lifeguards will be on duty.  Children under age 16 

must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule will be strictly enforced. 
 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion.  Please use caution. 
 

3. All residents are required to show their pool pass and a valid State of Texas ID if requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply 
may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 
 

4. The access gates can only be opened with a pool access card/fob.  Gates are to remain locked at all times.  The Pool Monitors 
have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access card/fob.  Anyone without an access card/fob will

On Thu, Apr 17, 2025 at 11:27 AM Chris Davis <daviscm75@gmail.com> wrote:
I am disputing the validity of the "violation". The codes you have sighted are vague and
subjective. "Miscellaneous" or "unsightly" items cannot be defined by one person. What
one person finds "unsightly" or even "miscellaneous" can be seen by others as beautiful
or useful. There are many items in people's yard and driveways throughout all of
Chandler Creek that I would never dream of putting on display or even letting be in my
yard. I would never dream of complaining about them just because I don't like it. And
I'm definitely not giving you specific addresses for you to investigate. It makes me
wonder if the best course of action would be just to ignore communication of this kind?
I can't imagine the justification of kitchen equipment, tarp covered vehicles,
collapsible/foldable chairs, old holiday decorations, broken lawn decorations and other
"miscellaneous" and "unsightly" items to be allowed to stay in plain sight for as long as

2014 Annual Meeting 

Proxy 

 
KNOW ALL MEN BY THESE PRESENTS, that the undersigned Homeowner in The Homeowners' 

Association for Chandler Creek, Inc. does hereby constitute, authorize, and appoint: (please check one of 

the options below) 

 

     Option #1 ____________________________________ (name) (someone who will attend the meeting 

on your behalf) 

 

By this designation of proxy, the Proxy may attend and represent the Homeowner with the full power to 

vote and act for the Homeowner in the same manner, to the extent and with the same effect as if the 

Homeowner were personally present. 

 

     Option #2 A Director of the Board who is not running for re-election for both voting and quorum 

purposes as the Proxy for the Homeowner to act on behalf of Homeowner at the Annual Meeting of 

members of The Homeowners' Association for Chandler Creek, Inc., and at any adjournment of the 

Annual Meeting or any subsequent meeting called to conduct or complete the Annual Meeting. 

 

The Proxy shall have full power to represent the Homeowner and vote on all issues and motions that are 

properly presented at the meeting(s) for which this designation of proxy is effective. The Proxy shall have 

the authority to vote entirely at the discretion of the Proxy. 

 

     Option #3 This proxy is to be used for quorum purposes only. The proxy will be held by a 

Director not running but will not be used for their voting privileges.   
     

Unless sooner terminated, this voting instrument shall terminate automatically upon the final adjournment 

of the Annual Meeting for which it is given. 

 

 

EXECUTED this____________ day of _____________________, 2014 

 

__________________________________________________________________________________

PASSED AND APPROVED this 17th day of January, 2023. 
      
 

     /s/ Walter Berry      
     President, Board of Directors 
     The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal Utility District 
 
ATTEST: 
 
/s/ Adrian Bustillos      
Secretary, Board of Directors 
The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal Utility District 
  



3 
 

EXHIBIT A 
 

1. The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal Utility District Homeowners’ Association 
Board (the “HOA”) reviews Deed Restriction violations and by vote determines which 
should be elevated to The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal Utility District (the 
“District”). 

 
2. The District Board reviews the forwarded Deed Restrictions and by vote determines 

whether the District should proceed in accordance with the Violation of District Rules 
Order adopted on July 16, 2019. 
 

3. If the District Board votes to move forward with enforcement the Board will review the 
deed restriction violations and vote on the appropriate fine in accordance with the fine 
schedule in the Deed Restriction Enforcement Resolution adopted on December 15, 2020.  
 

4. After District Board approval to move forward with enforcement, the District will afford 
residents a two-week grace period as an opportunity to cure a violation before a first offense 
violation will be issued. This grace-period does not extend beyond a first offense. This 
grace period is offered at the discretion of the District Board. 
 

5. Fine Schedule (pursuant to the Deed Restriction Enforcement Resolution):   
 

Landscaping Violations: 
• First offense: up to $100 
• Second or additional violation of same offense: up to $200 (or [d]ouble the fine 

for the first offense)

documents.content:
on July 16, 2019, the District is authorized to enforce deed 
restrictions for each subdivision as rules of the District. 

 
WHEREAS, pursuant to A RESOLUTION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE 

MEADOWS AT CHANDLER CREEK MUNICIPAL UTILITY DISTRICT: ESTABLISHING 
PROCEDURES FOR PROCESSING DEED RESTRICTION VIOLATIONS AND RELATED 
COMPLAINTS; PROVIDING FINDINGS OF FACT; PROVIDING FOR OPEN MEETING; 
PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE, (the “Deed Restriction Enforcement Resolution”), 
approved and ordered by the Board of Directors of the District on December 15, 2020, the District 



2 
 

established rules of procedure for processing and considering deed restriction violations and 
related complaints. 

 
WHEREAS, the District desires to amend its Deed Restriction Enforcement Resolution to 

allow for a grace period before District enforcement. 
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF 

THE MEADOWS AT CHANDLER CREEK MUNICIPAL UTILITY DISTRICT THAT: 

1. Findings of Fact. The preceding recitals are the true and correct findings of fact of 
the Board and are fully incorporated herein for all purposes. 
 

2. Rules of Procedure.  The procedures attached hereto, and fully incorporated, as 
Exhibit A will govern the Board’s actions in handling deed restriction violations 
within the District. 
 

3. No Waiver.  (a) While the Board will endeavor to adhere to the aforesaid 
procedures, the Board may, in its sole discretion, forgo such rules and proceed 
directly to legal action against the property owner or resident, or take other action 
authorized under law, to remedy ongoing violations. (b)  No provision of this 
Resolution may be interpreted so as to constitute a waiver of the District’s rights or 
authority provided under Section 54.237, Texas Water Code, or other law. 
 

4. Open Meeting.  The Board considered this Resolution during a duly noticed 
meeting that was open to the public, in compliance with Chapter 551, Texas 
Government Code.

A RESOLUTION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE MEADOWS 
AT CHANDLER CREEK MUNICIPAL UTILITY DISTRICT AMENDING 
PROCEDURES FOR PROCESSING DEED RESTRICTION VIOLATIONS 
AND RELATED COMPLAINTS; PROVIDING FINDINGS OF FACT; 
PROVIDING FOR OPEN MEETING; PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE 

 
WHEREAS, The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal Utility District (“District”) is a 

political subdivision of the State of Texas, created and operating under Chapters 49 and 54, Texas 
Water Code, as amended; and  

 
WHEREAS, subsection 54.237(a), Texas Water Code, defines a “restriction” as “a 

limitation on the use of real property that is established or incorporated in properly recorded 
covenants, property restrictions, plats, plans, deeds, or other instruments affecting real property in 
a district and that has not been abandoned, waived, or properly rescinded”; and
documents.path: /drives/b!nslWL7oJf0GurAFazjx4oOabfa0q4iZMh47wxSLJiqST3qiwOUFDQ6RKwkvmcuX4/root:/Chandler Creek HOA/Public/Meetings/2025 Board Meetings Chandler Creek/2025/August 2025/Chandler Creek -8-28-25/Meeting Packet/2023_01-23 Meadows of Chandler Creek MUD - Amendment to Deed Restrictions Order.pdf

documents.content:
recorded 
covenants, property restrictions, plats, plans, deeds, or other instruments affecting real property in 
a district and that has not been abandoned, waived, or properly rescinded”; and 

 
WHEREAS, subsection 54.237(b), Texas Water Code, provides that, “A district may take 

all actions necessary to enforce a restriction, including the initiation, defense, or intervention in 
litigation or an administrative proceeding to enjoin or abate the violation of a restriction when, in 
the reasonable judgment of the board of directors of the district, enforcement of the restriction is 
necessary to sustain taxable property values in the district”; and 

 
WHEREAS, the District’s Board of Directors (“Board”) finds that sustaining the taxable 

property values in the District promotes the best interest of the District and its residents;   
 
WHEREAS, the Board finds that establishing rules of procedure for processing and 

considering deed restriction violations and related complaints serves the interests of justice and 
provides property owners with the opportunity to rectify such violations prior to the District 
initiating enforcement action in the courts of law; 

 
WHEREAS, pursuant to AN ORDER OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE 

MEADOWS AT CHANDLER CREEK MUNICIPAL UTILITY DISTRICT; ESTABLISHING 
VIOLATIONS OF CERTAIN DEED RESTRICTIONS AS VIOLATIONS OF DISTRICT 
RULES; ESTABLISHING VIOLATIONS OF STATE LAW AS VIOLATIONS OF DISTRICT 
RULES; PROVIDING FINDINGS OF FACT; PROVIDING PENALTIES UP TO $10,000.00 
PER VIOLATION; PROVIDING FOR REPEAL OF CONFLICTING PROVISIONS; 
PROVIDING FOR SEVERABILITY; PROVIDING FOR OPEN MEETING; PROVIDING AN 
EFFECTIVE DATE, (the “Violation of District Rules Order”), approved and ordered by the 
Board of Directors of the District on July 16, 2019, the District is authorized to enforce deed 
restrictions for each subdivision as rules of the District. 

 
WHEREAS, pursuant to A RESOLUTION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE

CERTIFICATE FOR ORDER OR RESOLUTION 

THE STATE OF TEXAS 
COUNTY OF WILLIAMSON 

The undersigned officers of the Board of Directors of The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal 
Utility District of Williamson County, Texas (the "District") hereby certify as follows: 

The Board of Directors of The Meadows at Chandler Creek Municipal Utility District convened in 
regular session on the 17th day of January 2023, at 2112 Agarita Trail, (HOA Pool House Meeting Room), 
Round Rock, Texas, 78664, a location within the boundaries of the District, and the roll was called of the duly 
constituted officers and members of the Board, to wit: 

Walter Berry President 
Shelley Janda Vice President 
Adrian Bustillos Secretary 
Cassandra Brown Treasurer 
Stephen Reimund Asst. Secretary/Treasurer 

and all of said persons were present, except for the following absentees: Shelley Janda_, thus constituting 
a quorum. Whereupon, among other business, the following was transacted at the meeting: 

A RESOLUTION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE MEADOWS AT 
CHANDLER CREEK MUNICIPAL UTILITY DISTRICT AMENDING 
PROCEDURES FOR PROCESSING DEED RESTRICTION VIOLATIONS AND 
RELATED COMPLAINTS; PROVIDING FINDINGS OF FACT; PROVIDING FOR 
OPEN MEETING; PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE 

was introduced for the consideration of the Board. It was then duly moved and seconded that the Order of 
Resolution be adopted, and, after due discussion, the motion, can-ying with it the adoption of the Order or 
Resolution prevailed and carried by the following vote: 

AYES: 4 
NOES: 0 

That a true, full and correct copy of the aforesaid Order or Resolution adopted at the meeting described 
in the above and foregoing paragraph is attached to and follows this certificate; and that said Order or 
Resolution has been duly recorded in said Board's minutes of said meeting; that the persons named in the 
above and foregoing paragraph were duly chosen, qualified and acting officers and members of the Board as

documents.content:
Enforcement Resolution):   
 

Landscaping Violations: 
• First offense: up to $100 
• Second or additional violation of same offense: up to $200 (or [d]ouble the fine 

for the first offense) 
• Continuous Violations: 

o The fine for a first, second or additional violation; and 
o A periodic continuing fine of up to $200 per day, up to a maximum of 

$10,000 
 
Construction/Architectural Control Violations: 

• First offense: up to $200 
• Second or additional violation of same offense: up to $400  
• Continuous Violations: 

o The fine for a first, second or additional violation; and 
o A periodic continuing fine of up to $200 per day, up to a maximum of 

$10,000 
 
Violations of Other Restrictions: 

• First offense: up to $300 
• Second or additional violation of same offense: up to $400 
• Continuous Violations: 

o The fine for a first, second or additional violation; and 
o A periodic continuing fine of up to $200 per day, up to a maximum of 

$10,000 



4 
 

 
Violations That Create an Immediate Danger to Person or Property: 

• First offense: up to $400 
• Second or additional violation of same offense: Double the fine for the first 

offense 
• Continuous Violations: 

o The fine for a first, second or additional violation; and 
o A periodic continuing fine of up to $300 per day, up to a maximum of 

$10,000 
 

6. The [District] Board sends a Notice of Violation by certified and regular mail, along with 
a photo of the violation and copies of any previous notices sent to the Homeowner by the 
HOA. The letter is sent to both the property address and the mailing address if there is a 
difference. 

  
7. If the resident does not pay the penalty and/or remedy the violation the [District] Board 

will vote to determine if the matter should be pursued through court action.

Other Matter

The Homeowners' Association For Chandler Creek, Inc. has not estimated the remaining useful lives and 
replacement costs of common property and, therefore, management has omitted Supplementary 
Information on Future Major Repairs and Replacements that accounting principles generally accepted in 
the United States of America require to be presented to supplement the basic financial statements.  Such 
missing information, although not a part of the basic financial statements, is required by the Financial 
Accounting Standards Board, who considers it to be an essential part of financial reporting for placing 
the basic financial statements in an appropriate operational, economic, or historical context.  Our opinion 
on the basic financial statements is not affected by the missing information.  

Armstrong, Vaughan & Associates, P.C.

documents.content:
funds for major repairs and replacements should be accounted for in separate certificates of deposit and 
savings accounts and generally are not available for expenditures for normal operations. 

The Association has not conducted a study to determine the remaining useful lives of the 
components of common property and current estimates of costs of major repairs and replacements that 
may be required in the future.  The Board has also not developed a plan to fund those needs.  When 
replacement funds are needed to meet future needs for major repairs and replacements, the Association 
has the right to increase regular assessments, pass special assessments, or delay major repairs and 
replacements until funds are available.  The effect on future assessments has not been determined at this; 
however, the effect could be material.

NOTE 4 -- INCOME TAXES

Accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America require the Association 
management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Association and recognize a tax liability (or asset) if 
the Association has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon 
examination by the Internal Revenue Service. Management has analyzed the tax positions taken by the 
Association, and has concluded that as of December 31, 2013, there are no uncertain positions taken or 
expected to be taken that would require recognition as a liability (or asset) or disclosure in the financial 
statements. The Association is subject to routine examinations by taxing authorities; however, there are 
currently no examinations for any tax periods in progress. Management believes it is no longer subject to 
income tax examinations for years prior to 2010.



8

THE HOMEOWNERS' ASSOCIATION FOR CHANDLER CREEK, INC.
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (CONT.)

DECEMBER 31, 2013

NOTE 4 -- INCOME TAXES (CONT.)

results.details: The HOA contracts with Ecosystems Landscape Services to maintain community lands

extracted.answer: The HOA contracts with Ecosystems Landscape Services to maintain community landscaping. The landscaping maintenance covers communal areas, with services including weekly maintenance during growing season (March to October), mowing, debris cleanup, irrigation monitoring, and other landscape care services.

extracted.quote: Entire property will be maintained as one site, meaning same general maintenance performed on all areas.
extracted.source: Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8-31-22.pdf
extracted.summary: Landscape maintenance is handled by a professional landscaping company for the entire community, with specified seasonal services and maintenance protocols

documents.content:
1700 Dungan Ln.  Austin, TX  78754 office 512-977-0052 fax 512-977-0092 

 

 

August 31, 2022 

Chandler Creek HOA (“Customer”) 

2323 Agarita Trail, Round Rock, TX 78665 

LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT 

 

GENERAL ITEMS 

1) Ecosystems Landscape Services (Company) proposes to provide all materials, labor, 

supervision, and all necessary insurance to perform the services as listed below.  Entire 

property will be maintained as one site, meaning same general maintenance performed 

on all areas. 

2) The purpose of this landscape management plan is to ensure that Company provides first 

class service to our customer. 

3) Property will have always a neat, clean, healthy, and manicured appearance after visits. 

4) Property will have an assigned Account Manager to assure that all services provided 

follow this agreement. Company shall remain vigilant and constantly be on the look-out 

for damage to the landscape and shall notify Customer as soon as possible for Customer 

to take corrective action. 

5) Property shall be maintained utilizing appropriate technology, equipment, and industry 

accepted techniques such that all turf and landscape ground covers, shrubs, and trees 

remain vigorous, healthy, and visually acceptable. 

6) Crew members shall be properly trained and supervised and in proper uniform always. 

7) Any dumped and/or piled debris, large limbs, and/or fallen trees to be removed and billed 

on Time and Materials basis upon approval from Customer and/or Management 

Company. 

8) No on-site dumpsters will be utilized, or on-site disposal will be performed, unless 

specifically addressed in this agreement.   

9) Porter Services are not included in this agreement. 



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   2  

10) Clean up of all landscape debris generated during regular maintenance visits, to include 

leaves, small limbs, twigs, etc., to be cleaned up as part of regular service in areas as

documents.content:
be priced and must be approved by the Customer prior to the specific service 

being performed. The prices quoted above are only valid if included in the base contract 

at the time of signing.  

➢ Plant and grass replacements/renovations are available and priced according to scope. 

➢ Granite trail repairs, available upon request and priced according to scope of work.  

➢ Clean-up of trash and debris not generated by regular maintenance in areas not 

maintained by Company, such as: parking areas, streets, driveways, sport courts, fenced 

in areas, swimming pools, and other Hardscape areas not in Company maintenance areas 

or scope of work.   

➢ Installation of Certified Playscape Mulch available and priced according to scope of 

work. 

➢ Installation and Maintenance of Playscape Equipment is available and priced 

accordingly. The Company does not install but can oversee Certified Installers if 

necessary.   

➢ Installation of additional shredded hardwood mulch available based on quantity, scope 

of work, etc.  

➢ Installation of “Native Grind” mulch available and priced according to scope of work. 

➢ Re-seeding of areas, preferably in October, available as needed and upon Customer 

approval of cost. Over-seed rate will be 23# per acre (exact ratio to be determine) 

consisting of annuals and perennials. Flowers from spring to early summer weather 

dependent. Germination and flowering are based on weather conditions. Seed is fresh 

and viable.  



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   11  

➢ Aeration & topdressing of all irrigated turf areas, and at an approximate recommended 

depth of ¼” of top-dressing mix.  The timeframe for this service is weather dependent 

and the depth is an average. Some areas may need more and some less depending on turf 

type, density, etc. This service is best to be performed in March/April. Topdressing 

service is not designed to level all areas.

4) Company is not responsible for items left in shared areas, turf areas etc., such as “yard 

art”, signs, figurines, etc. that may be damaged during normal use of landscape 

equipment to include but not limited to blowers, weed eaters, etc. 

5) Pesticides, fertilizers, etc. will not be applied if animals/people are present and since they 

are time sensitive certain areas may not receive important services, i.e., pre-emergent, 

fire ant treatment, etc. in the correct timeframe. 



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   3  

SERVICE MAP 

 

EXPLANATION OF SCHEDULE 

1) Schedule is a basic guideline for services and subject to change based upon best 

agronomic practices.  Any major changes will be addressed with Customer ahead of time. 

2) Application date for fertilizer, mulch installation, weed control, fungicide, etc. are 

subject to change based on weather conditions, leaf drop, etc. and agronomic needs and 

do not affect the scope of work for this agreement. 

3) Areas with forty-two (42) visits means all services to performed weekly as needed during 

the growing season, which is roughly the first or second week of March thru about the 

third or fourth week of October.   



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   4  

4) Areas listed as monthly will be most likely be done the same week each month, weather 

permitting.   

5) The “off-season” is considered November- February.   Off season visits will consist only 

with mowing only as needed and includes detail work of beds, trees, trash clean up, etc.    

6) Exact visits per month may vary based on fluctuating weeks in any given month per year.   

Weekly services in off season are only twice monthly for all areas; therefore, specific

documents.content:
shall be pruned during dormant season to 

maintain proper appearance.  

IRRIGATION SERVICE AND MAINTENANCE 

1) This agreement only covers the communal area irrigation system. The Customer is 

responsible for providing the water to the system.    



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   9  

2) Irrigation will be monitored during regular maintenance visits.  If issues arise, licensed 

irrigation crew will be dispatched to perform corrective measures.      

3) Minor head adjustments, cleaning of nozzles, and heads, spray patterns adjusted to 

improve water coverage, arc, and radius adjustments as necessary on all rotor zones and 

included in service during regular inspections. All other repairs will be billed 

accordingly.  

4) The irrigation systems will have a monthly inspection and will be adjusted accordingly 

to insure proper moisture levels, as possible, for landscaped plant material.  Timelines 

for irrigation inspections may vary as Company may combine inspection with an 

irrigation service visit, when possible, to minimize additional costs to the HOA.    

5) Repairs and operation of these systems shall comply with TCEQ, City/MUD and/or 

applicable authorized government entity rules and regulations.  

6) If prior approval is required by Customer for irrigation repairs, the system may be shut 

down upon completion of the inspection and/or if an issue arises between monthly 

inspections and if it is determined by the Company that operation of the system will 

violate any governmental rules and/or regulations, to include runoff, over spray, broken 

lines, etc. Company shall not be responsible for any issues arising from irrigation system 

being turned off, to include damage to the landscape.    

7) Local watering restrictions may affect specific watering times and usage.    

8) Irrigation systems will be adjusted as part of this agreement with scheduled visit to keep

✓ The scope of services shall include all labor and equipment, tools, supplies plus any 

materials, taxes, permits and fees (unless expressly excluded and so indicated, herein), 

necessary to perform this work.  The work includes seasonal landscape maintenance 

services required to maintain the health and appearance of the landscape. 



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   12  

✓ The landscape shall be well maintained utilizing appropriate technology, equipment, and 

industry accepted techniques such that all turf and landscape ground covers, shrubs and 

trees remain vigorous, healthy, and visually acceptable.    

✓ The Company reserves the right to renegotiate this contract during the existing term only 

if the scope of work changes and/or if the price or scope of work is affected by local, 

state, or federal regulations and/or ordinance.  Tax rate changes are automatic and do not 

affect the contract.   

✓ At the end of this agreement, renewal shall be automatic at existing current rates, unless 

canceled and/or amended in writing, by either party at least 45 days prior to the end of 

this agreement, for a period of 12 months.  

✓ All work described herein is converted to the Company’s work order upon authorization.  

Work that has only been discussed verbally WILL NOT be performed unless it is also 

itemized above.   

✓ Either party may cancel this contract at any time with sixty (60) day written notice.  

✓ If for any reason this contract shall not be fulfilled, the Company shall compare the 

services provided, including amortized services, i.e., mulch, flowers, etc., to the property 

with the total payment received.   

✓ Should the Customer have paid for services not completed, Company will refund this 

amount within thirty (30) days of request.

of the existing growth during 

visits will be made.  Use of specific types of equipment will be utilized and/or adjusted 

to minimize scalping and always perform best practices for the turf. 

10) All irregularly cut grass around buildings, signage, posts, trees, and other raised objects 

to be trimmed/edged as needed with each scheduled visit. 

11) Turf areas directly abutting bed areas will be mowed in manner as to avoid discharge of 

clippings into the shrub beds and tree wells. 

12) Line trimmers shall be used for edging purposes only and will not be used to cut turf 

areas horizontally, except in areas mowers cannot reach. 

HARDSCAPE and BED AREAS 

1) Non-Selective herbicide spraying of weeds in expansion joints, open bed and rock areas 

as needed and as maintained only.    

2) Company does not maintain color beds installed by others, to include the residents. 

3) Clean up of all landscape debris generated during regular maintenance visits, to include 

leaves, in areas as maintained as needed with each regular visit.  



Chandler Creek HOA Landscape Management Agreement 8/31/22 

   6  

4) Manual removal of large weeds in beds and smaller weeds to be chemically treated to 

better help maintain control of resurgence of weeds.  

5) Curb lines and paved areas shall be cleaned of debris generated by Company during 

regular visits in areas as maintained.    

6) Curb openings to be kept free of landscape debris to allow for proper drainage in areas 

we maintain only.  

7) Mulch – not included at this time. To be addressed later with Customer. 

SHURBS/GROUNDCOVERS 

1) Trimming of shrubs based on specific plant types to include removing deadwood and 

maintaining proper size/shape and to encourage proper growth.   

2) Flowering shrubs shall be pruned after blooming cycle in a manner to promote new 

blooms.  

3) Regular service does not include damage caused by storms, vandals, etc. or other issues 

not under Company’s control.

✓ Therefore, the Company warrants and represents that it:   

✓ Will perform the services in a good and skillful manner.  

✓ Will if it is not able to perform a specific regular weekly service due to weather 

conditions or other conditions not under its control, correct the issue on the next regular 

maintenance visit, with no adjustment in billing.  

✓ Will comply with all applicable laws with respect to its performance of such services.  

✓ It is responsible for its employees that perform such services.  

✓ Has adequate insurance and will add Customer as additional insured upon request.  

✓ Maintains workers’ compensation insurance and general liability insurance.  

✓ Will perform all services with trained and/or licensed personnel as required by local, 

state and/or federal laws.  

✓ Governing Law: This Agreement has been executed and delivered in, and shall be 

interpreted, construed, and enforced pursuant to and in accordance with the laws of the

A PROGRAM OF INSURANCE PROTECTION

Homeowners Association for Chandler Creek, Inc. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
 

SUBMITTED BY 

 

SCARBROUGH, MEDLIN & ASSOCIATES, INC. 

Kylie Proffitt 

EFFECTIVE 

09/08/2024 – 09/08/2025 



Homeowners Association for Chandler Creek, Inc. 

 
 

GENERAL INFORMATION 
 

The description of coverage included in this proposal is expressed in general terms and 

conditions of coverage are shown in the policies. Nothing in this proposal  alters,  changes, 

or replaces any policy contract. This is a proposal for coverage and not a binder of 

insurance. 

 

THE BEST RATINGS 
 

The A. M. Best Company is to the insurance industry what Standard & Poor and Moody 

are to the financial markets. It rates insurance companies with respect to their overall 

performance in managing the company for policyholders and investors, and it categorizes 

companies according to their financial size. Companies given an A or A+ rating have 

demonstrated a continuing ability to underwrite risks competently, control costs, make wise 

investments, and absorb catastrophic losses. 

 

The financial size category is determined by the surplus to policyholders, reserves, and 

capital of the company. 

 

We have listed below the Best's ratings for each of the proposed carriers for your insurance 

program. We feel it is important that you are confident in the quality and strength of the 

insurers protecting your asset.

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it 
otherwise holds rights or obligations.1 

"Development Area" means a part of the Development that is subject to additional restrictions set 
forth in a Development Area Declaration that applies to such property.2 

"Development Area Declaration" means, with respect to any Development Area, a separate 
instrument containing covenants, restrictions, conditions, limitations and/or easements, 
applicable to the property.3 

"Greenbelt/Open Space Lots" are portions of the Property that are designated on a Plat or in an 
instrument as property to be used as a greenbelt, open space, or a drainage easement and not for 
use as a residential lot. Open space areas may also include fenced karst feature areas, greenbelts 
and re-irrigation areas owned by the Association. Use is restricted to permitted uses only (e.g., 
use of trails established by the Association in accordance with applicable rules or trimming the 
twenty foot (20') strip behind an Owner's fence and property line in accordance with the 
Association's Rules). Otherwise, trespassing is prohibited.4

2 Declaration, Definitions. 
3 Declaration, Definitions. 
4 Design Guidelines. 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE4

garages, driveways, parking areas and/or facilities, storage buildings, sidewalks, fences, gates, 
screening walls, retaining walls, stairs, patios, decks, walkways, landscaping, mailboxes, poles,

responsibility of each Owner to ensure that they have the most current edition of the Design 
Guidelines and every amendment thereto. 

Development Restrictions 

Environmental Restrictions. Portions of Highpointe are located in areas with sensitive 
environmental features. Accordingly, there are limitations, including impervious cover 
restrictions, on development activity in the subdivision. The recorded plats for the subdivision 
are accessible at the following link: https://hayscad.com/subdivisionplats/sublisth/. The plats 
contain information about setbacks, greenbelt lots, and use restrictions. The plats should be 
reviewed along with the recorded governing documents for Highpointe. 

Use of Adjacent Lots. As a general rule, property that is adjacent to your lot that you do not own 
may not be used as an extension of your property. 

Maintaining Adjacent Lots. If your rear property line is adjacent to a greenbelt lot owned by the 
Association, in most cases you have the right to weed eat the property to a distance of up to 20 
feet beyond your rear fence and you may remove small brush and dead cedar trees. All debris, 
branches, leaves, and clippings must be removed from the property. 

Architectural Review. With few exceptions, improvements must be approved by the Association 
in writing before work commences. When in doubt, please inquire by contacting the Association. 
It is NOT better to ask for forgiveness then permission where approval is concerned. The 
governing documents, including the Design Guidelines, contain additional rules pertaining to 
use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system.

THIS DOCUMENT AMENDS AND RESTATES THE HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES 
RECORDED AS DOCUMENT NO. 201111026548 IN THE OFFICIAL PUBLIC RECORDS OF 
HAYS COUNTY, TEXAS AND ANY AMENDMENTS OR SUPPLEMENTS THERETO. 



23018808 Page 2 of 42 

Introduction 

Background. Highpointe is a master-planned community located in Hays County, Texas. The 
governing body for the subdivision is the HP Property Owners Association, Inc. (the 
11 Association"). The community is subject to the terms and provisions of the First Amended and 
Restated Master Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions - Highpointe Residential, 
recorded in the Official Public Records of Hays County, Texas (as amended, the "Declaration"). 
Within the subdivision there are Development Areas, each of which will be subject to a certain 
Development Area Declaration instrument. The recorded instruments contain important rules 
that Owners are bound by. Capitalized terms used herein but not defined are to be given those 
definitions found in the Declaration. 

The Master Architectural Control Committee 

WRITTEN PRE-APPROVAL IS REQUIRED FOR IMPROVEMENTS. Under Article VI of the

Fencing 

Fencing of front yards is not allowed. Solid walls enclosing an entire site are not permitted. All 
Lots shall have fencing of 6 feet in height and no portion of any fencing may exceed 6 feet in 
height. Fences shall be of wood, black coated wrought iron or decorative metal construction 
approved by the Master Architectural Control Committee. The Fence must be located 10 feet 
from the front elevation of the residence and no farther from the front elevation of the residence 
than the midpoint of the residence. In the event of any dispute or disagreement as to the location 
of a fence on a Lot, the decision of the Master Architectural Control Committee, in it sole and 
absolute discretion, will be final. 

• Wood fences facing an existing or proposed street or other right-of-way must have the 
slats facing the street or public right-of-way and must be stained with "Behr #501 Semi­
Transparent Cedar Tone" or such other natural or neutral colors approved by the Master 
Architectural Control Committee All other fencing between residential lots must be 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE27 



23018808 Page 28 of 42 

"good neighbor fencing". Good Neighbor fencing is defined as wood fencing that 
alternates the side the panel faces every eight feet (8'). Neighbors are permitted to vary 
from this requirement; provided, however, that any such deviation from the Good 
Neighbor Fencing requirement must be, in writing, signed by the Owners of both Lots 
impacted by the agreement, and submitted to the Association with a request for approval 
before installation. The agreement must also provide the period of time that the 
arrangement shall remain in place. 

• Fences along the side yard of corner lots shall not be placed closer to the public right-of­

Front yard fencing is discouraged. However, if an owner wishes to install security fencing in the 
front yard, the fencing must consist of ornamental wrought iron or metal fencing (painted black) 
with the following general specifications: Pickets ¾" square; Rails 1 ½" square; Standard Posts 2 
½" square; Picket Spacing between 3" and 4"; Post Spacing 8' OC; Height between 48" and 60". 
Slats, planks, or other solid material may not be installed on metal fencing. 

Basketball Goals and Sporting Equipment 

Basketball goals, or backboards, or any other similar sporting equipment of either a permanent or 
temporary nature shall not be placed on any Lot or street or where same would be visible from 
an adjoining street or Lot without the prior written consent of the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. 

Permanent goals must meet the following criteria: 
• the metal pole must be permanently mounted into the ground to the side of the driveway 

in a full upright position 25' back from the curb; 
• the pole, backboard and net must be maintained in good condition at all times; and 
• poles may not be installed in front of the garage or facing into the street. 

Portable goals will not be allowed unless the following criteria are met: 
• the goal must be placed to the side of the driveway and permanently installed to be flush 

with the ground and maintained at all times in a full upright position 25' back from the 
curb; 

• the pole, backboard and net must be maintained in good condition at all times; 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE 30 



23018808 Page 31 of 42 

• poles may not be installed in front of the garage or facing the street; 
• landscape barrier, such as small shrubs must screen the base of the goal; 
• goals may not be rolled into the street or any other public right-of-way; and

documents.content:
by local building codes and have all applicable building 
permits in place before construction begins. 

• All materials used match those of the home, including siding, brick, windows, and paint 
color, shingles, etc. 

• The improvement must be compatible with the architectural elements of the existing 
house. Paint colors and materials must match those of the house. 

• The design should reflect consideration for any adverse impact of neighboring 
properties. 

• Supplemental landscaping may be required as part of the Master Architectural Control 
Committee review. 

• The roof of the detached buildings shall match the roof of the house. 

NOTE: The approval of an accessory building, including a pool house, detached home office, or 
other detached building shall not be construed as approval to deviate from the single-family use 
restriction applicable to a Lot. 

Greenbelt/Open Space Lots 

Lots Adjacent to Greenbelt/Open Space Lots must comply with all of the following requirements: 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE 12 



23018808 Page 13 of 42 

1. Platted Boundary Lines. Individual homeowner lots end at the rear fence or rear property 
line. 

2. Fencing. The boundary between the Lot and the Greenbelt/Open Space Lots must be fenced 
in a manner approved in advance by the Master Architectural Control Committee. The fence 
must be six feet (6') high and be built of "black powder coated" wrought iron or other 
decorative metal of a color and style specified by the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. 

3. Gates. No gate will be permitted into a Greenbelt/Open Space Lot without the prior written 
approval of the Master Architectural Control Committee. 

4. Backyard Landscaping Requirements. Backyards must be fully sodded with at least two 3" 
caliper hardwood trees installed by the Owner. 

5. No Personal Use of Greenbelt/Open Space Lots. At no time are Greenbelt/Open Space Lots 
to be used for ingress/egress or storage.

documents.content:
room windows and kitchen windows. 

Supplemental lighting of sport courts in any form is not permitted. 

For the avoidance of doubt and in conjunction with existing restrictions regarding noise and 
nuisance considerations, activity on Sport Courts shall be limited from dawn to dusk. 

Erosion Control and Construction Regulations 

The following restrictions shall apply to all construction activities at Highpointe. Periodic 
inspections by a representative of the Master Architectural Control Committee may take place in 
order to identify non-complying construction activities. If items identified as not complying with 
the regulations are not remedied in a timely manner, fines will be levied. 

Erosion Control Installation and Maintenance 

It is the responsibility of each Owner to install erosion control measures prior to the start of 
construction and to maintain them throughout the entire construction process. 

Silt fencing installed to all applicable standards is required to be properly installed and 
maintained to protect the low sides of all disturbed areas, where stormwater will flow during 
construction. The purpose of the silt fence is to capture the sediment from the runoff and to 
permit filtered, clean water to exit the site. The Owner should anticipate that built-up sediment 
will need to be removed from the silt fence after heavy or successive rains, and that any breach in 
the fencing will need to be repaired or replaced immediately. 

If for any reason the silt fence is to be temporarily removed, please contact a representative of the 
Master Architectural Control Committee prior to the removal. 

Security 

Neither the Master Architectural Control Committee, the Association, nor the Declarant shall be 
responsible for the security of job sites during construction. 

Construction Hours 

Unless a written waiver is obtained from the Master Architectural Control Committee,

documents.content:

down to prevent wind from blowing such materials off the construction site. 

The dumping, burying or burning of trash is not permitted anywhere in Highpointe. 

It is imperative that, when moving heavy equipment around, precautions be taken to prevent 
damage to pavement, curbs, and vegetation. Crawler tractors are not to be operated on paved or 
concrete surfaces. Mud, dirt and other construction debris that is tracked off site shall be cleaned 
on a daily basis. 

Sanitary Facilities 

A temporary sanitary facility ( chemical toilet) shall be provided and maintained for the use of 
construction workers. 

Construction Parking 

Construction crews shall not park on, or otherwise use, other Lots. No construction vehicle will 
be permitted to leak oil or otherwise damage or deface any street located within the community. 

Schedule of Fines 

Periodic inspections by a representative of the Master Architectural Control Committee 
may take place in order to identify non-complying construction activities. Listed below is 
the schedule of fines which may be assessed. 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE33

provide necessary service to bring the improvement into compliance, the Owner 
will be assessed the cost of repair, clean up, or service plus an additional 50% for 
time and service expended. 

Duration of Construction 

A residence shall be complete and available for occupancy on or before eighteen (18) months 
after the start of construction.

documents.content:
Pools, Spas and Hot Tub Plans 

Above-ground or temporary swimming pools are expressly prohibited. 

The plans and specifications for each swimming pool, spa and hot tub constructed on a Lot must 
be approved in writing and prior to construction by the Master Architectural Control Committee. 
All applications submitted to the Master Architectural Control Committee for the approval of 
plans and specifications for swimming pools, hut tubs or spas must be accompanied by the 
applicable city permits for the construction of same. Any applications submitted to the Master 
Architectural Control Committee, which do not include finalized construction permits from the 
city shall constitute an automatic rejection of the application. Above-ground or temporary 
swimming pools are prohibited. Each swimming pool constructed on a Lot must be entirely 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE28 



23018808 Page 29 of 42 

enclosed with a fence or similar structure which, at a mm1mum, satisfies all applicable 
governmental requirements. The location, color and style of the fence or enclosure must be 
approved in writing and in advance of construction by the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. The Master Architectural Control Committee may require that a swimming pool, spa 
and hot tub constructed on a Lot and associated Improvements be enclosed with a fence or 
similar structure irrespective of governmental requirements. Approval of a swimming pool, spa 
and hot tub and/or associated Improvements by the Master Architectural Control Committee will 
not constitute a determination by the Master Architectural Control Committee that the swimming 
pool, spa and hot tub and/or associated Improvements comply with governmental requirements 
or that the swimming pool, spa and hot tub and/or associated Improvements are safe for use. The 
Master Architectural Control Committee may require an Owner to install additional screening as

documents.content:
be considered and action(s) toward resolution will be at the Board's discretion. 

1. The Chandler Creek HOA swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pool.  No lifeguards are on duty.  Children 
under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule is 
strictly enforced. 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion. Please use caution. 

3. All Chandler Creek HOA residents are required to show their pool access pass device and a valid State of Texas ID if 
requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 

4. The access gates can only be opened with your assigned pool access device.  Gates are to remain closed/locked at all 
times.  The Pool Monitors have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access device.  Anyone 
without a pool access device will be asked to retrieve theirs before they will be allowed to enter the pool area.  Under 
no circumstances should the gate(s) be propped open.  There is a $20 replacement fee for lost/defective pool access 
devices. 

5. One household may host up to four (4) pool guests.  All pool guests must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA 
resident who remains at the pool during the guest’s visit. 

6. Chandler Creek homeowners have the authority to always enforce the current pool rules.  Conduct by any person 
deemed to be dangerous, unreasonable, or offensive (including “horseplay”) is not allowed and should be reported to 
the Pool Monitor.  Any individual disciplined repeatedly, or for serious infractions, may lose all pool privileges for the 
rest of the season. 

7. The kiddy pool is limited to children 5 years of age and younger.  Exceptions may be made for older children with injuries 
which would prevent them from safely entering the main pool.  Each child in the kiddy pool must have an adult 
supervisor;

Any individual(s) reported to be/or found to be in violation of any of these pool rules will be reported to the HOA Board,

(d) Trash cans indoors and outdoors are to be emptied and trash placed in the trash bins located in parking lot.
(e) Restrooms trash cans emptied and countertops wiped down.
(f) All furniture must be returned to its original position.
(g) All greenery, flowers, decorations and other items brought in must be removed.
(h) Pavilion, if used, should be swept, all trash cans emptied and furniture put back to its original place.
(i) All lights, appliances and fans must be turned off.
Failure to strictly comply with the cleaning requirements will result in forfeit of security deposit.

Damages: The ROA Member will be held responsible for any damage caused by the member and or their
guests. The breach or violation of any condition set forth herein may result in the loss of the security deposit,
the imposition of liability on the ROA Member, and possible denial of future rentals of the Clubhouse.

Right of Refusal: The Association reserves the right to refuse to rent the facilities for any purpose it deems to
be detrimental to or not in the best interests of its members. It further reserves the right to refuse to rent the
facilities on any dates and at any time it deems inappropriate or inconvenient to residents of La Ventana.

La Ventana Clubhouse Rental Rules, Regulations and Pool Rules 3



La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

● Noise must be kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.  In case of an emergency, call 911.  An emergency call box is located right outside of the front pool gate in the 
courtyard. 

22. Access to the multi-purpose room is by advance reservation only. 

Miscellaneous: 

Restrooms:  The restroom fixtures are sanitized and cleaned by a private janitorial service.  The designated maintenance 
person/company is responsible for cleaning mirrors, counters, stocking hand towels, soap, emptying trashed and cleaning 
the floors and toilets.  Please be mindful of other HOA members by cleaning up after yourself when using the restrooms.  If 
the restroom should require attention, please notify the Pool Monitor on duty or call the current HOA management 
company. 

Penalties for Violation of Pool Rules: 

Depending on upon severity of offense, action taken by the HOA for violation of HOA pool rues may include one or more of 
the following: 

• 1st offense – A written warning is issued (notification of registered homeowner, parent, or guardian, when 
applicable) 

• 2nd offense – A second written warning is issued. 

• 3rd offense – Pool privileges are revoked, and pool card deactivated. 

• Criminal and civil complaints are filed when applicable: 
1. Notification of Sheriff’s Office 
2. Prosecution and/or other legal remedies

use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system. 

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it 
otherwise holds rights or obligations.1 

"Development Area" means a part of the Development that is subject to additional restrictions set 
forth in a Development Area Declaration that applies to such property.2 

"Development Area Declaration" means, with respect to any Development Area, a separate 
instrument containing covenants, restrictions, conditions, limitations and/or easements, 
applicable to the property.3 

"Greenbelt/Open Space Lots" are portions of the Property that are designated on a Plat or in an 
instrument as property to be used as a greenbelt, open space, or a drainage easement and not for 
use as a residential lot. Open space areas may also include fenced karst feature areas, greenbelts 
and re-irrigation areas owned by the Association. Use is restricted to permitted uses only (e.g., 
use of trails established by the Association in accordance with applicable rules or trimming the 
twenty foot (20') strip behind an Owner's fence and property line in accordance with the 
Association's Rules). Otherwise, trespassing is prohibited.4

documents.content:
fibers can clog pool filters and create the need for expensive repairs. 

16. Children who are not toilet-trained are not allowed in either the main pool or the kiddy pool without a “swim” diaper 
and must always be accompanied by an adult within arm’s length.  Children wearing regular diapers are not allowed in 
either the main pool or the kiddy pool.  “Swim” diapers must always be used.  If your child or anyone else in your party 
is found to be responsible for a closure due to fecal matter, all costs to clean and reopen the pool may be assigned to 
your household via your HOA account.  If a fecal accident occurs: All swimmers must exit the pool immediately and the 
pool will be closed for the minimum time frame as allowed by law from the time the pool has been chemically treated.  
Incidents should be immediately reported to the current HOA management company and/or the Pool Monitor on duty. 

17. Persons having currently active diarrhea or who have had active diarrhea within the previous 14 days are not allowed to 
enter the pool water. 

18. No smoking or any other use of tobacco products (Skoal, chewing tobacco, vapor cigarettes, etc.).  The following are not 
permitted in the pool area or surrounding park under any circumstances: alcohol, firearms, or drugs.  Individuals 
engaging in the use of such are subject to loss of privileges for a period to be determined by the HOA Board. Other legal 
actions may be taken in conjunction with the Williamson County Sheriff’s Office. 

19. Swim safely and treat others as you would like to be treated.  Residents are responsible for the behavior of those in their 
household and/or their guests. 

20. In the event of inclement weather, swimmers are to clear the pool during the storm and for at least thirty (30) minutes 
after lightning and/or thunder has ceased. 

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.

documents.content:
ACCEPTABLE ITEMS 
• Bulky items such as stoves, water tanks, 

furniture, washing machines, and dryers. 
• Air conditioners, freezers, and refrigerators 

that are tagged verifying CFC’s have been 
removed by a certified technician  

• Lawn mowers:  Fuel and oil must be 
drained. 

• Bundled brush securely tied together and 
properly prepared ( 4-foot lengths, 4-inch 
diameter or 40 pounds in weight) and 
placed at curbside.  

• Total acceptable volume of bulky items 
and/or bundles is three (3) cubic yards 
measured 3’ x 3’ x 3’. 

 
UNACCEPTABLE ITEMS 

• Gasoline, motor oil, paint, chemicals, and 
similar flammable liquids. 

• Medical waste (including needles and 
syringes), animals or human waste. 

• Tires, batteries, and large pieces of metal 
(car fenders, engines, etc.) 

• Used oil filters or any hazardous or toxic 
waste. 

• CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL AND 
DEMOLITION DEBRIS – i.e. concrete, 
rebar, dirt, sheet rock, rocks, excelsior, 
gypsum board, metal rubber and wood. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

Saturday, December 7, 2019 
 

Cooper Lane Condos and Waste 
Connections will be holding a 

curbside cleanup on  
SATURDAY, December 7, 2019 

 Item(s) at curb no later than: 7:00 a.m. 
 

 
Waste Connections is proud to offer 
this service to current residential 
customers within the community 
limits of Cooper Lane Condos.  
 

A maximum of three (3) cubic yards of 
acceptable residential bulky items will be 
collected. Resident’s bulky items should be 
neatly placed at the curb by 7:00 a.m. on 
the scheduled pick-up.  

 
Note: Items placed at the curb later 
than 7:00 AM and/or exceeds the 3 
cubic yard limit will not be serviced. 
The resident will be responsible for 
arranging for proper disposal of 
anything put out after 7:00 a.m. or 
over the 3 cubic yard limit.  

 
 

NO BULKY WASTE SHOULD BE 
PLACED FOR COLLECTION PRIOR 

TO Friday, December 6th, 2019 
 

 
Questions? 
Contact Waste Connections Customer Service:  
Phone: 512-252-3508

get confused thinking they’ve set up all water services but have only

Spectrum, (512) 485-5555, https://www.spectrum.com/ 
• Residents might ask why Spectrum (formally Time Warner) is the only internet provider 

out at Highpointe. Please let them know that during the period of laying infrastructure 
that the developer set up a marking agreement with the company to exclusively run lines. 
Other internet providers are not prohibited to run lines; however, it would be extremely 
costly for them to do so now so they will decline setting up service in Highpointe.  

 
4.3 TRASH & BULK PICKUPS 
 

Trash day is Monday. Recycling is every other Monday. Since Highpointe is a private community, the 
POA has a contract in place for TDS to service all Highpointe residents. Even with this contract, residents 
are solely responsible to set up trash services. Trash services are NOT included in Highpointe dues. 
Residents are NOT allowed to use an alternative trash service. Trash cans may only be out the day of 



Highpointe POA Operations Manual 

 

Page | 10  CONFIDENTIAL TO FIRSTSERVICE RESIDENTIAL 

 

service (please be lenient on trash cans out Sunday evening and Tuesday morning when doing 
inspections).  

Each HP resident household may order from Texas Disposal Systems Inc (TDS) two FREE curbside 
bulky or brush waste collections per year. They can contact TDS (800) 375-8375 to schedule a collection.

WEEK in advance. All outside social event dates and locations need to be sent to Sunscapes so they make 
sure irrigation is not scheduled to go off before or during the event.  
 
Porters for Events: SJG Janitorial has porters for hire. Please schedule them to attend each Food Truck 
Friday and every large community event. The porter is scheduled in 4-hour blocks and will pickup trash, 
restock supplies and switch out trash bags as needed.   
 



Highpointe POA Operations Manual 

 

Page | 27  CONFIDENTIAL TO FIRSTSERVICE RESIDENTIAL 

 

Food Truck Friday: Typically these Food Truck Friday events are held on the First Friday of the month. 
We usually have a sponsor who will cover any costs (like for a DJ or alcohol). A few food 
trucks/sponsors who frequent: 
 

o Suds Monkey - Complimentary Beer 
o Westlake Power Washing Resident & Commercial - Complimentary Wine 
o Garbo’s Food Truck - Spin-off of a buzzy food truck spotlighting New England seafood 

in small space with coastal charm 
o Thin Blue Smokery Food Truck - The Texas Hill Country's premier barbecue 
o Connors Creamery – Ice Cream 
o The Brown Agency – Sponsor  
o Italian Ice – Snow Cones 
o Silver and Gold – Live Music 

 
BBQ Cook Off & Kickball Tournament – OCT (overnight)  
This is probably Highpointe’s biggest event of the year. Sponors will be needed or you can utilize the 
budget. Last year this was paid 100% by different sponsors. Dr. Ron White is the main sponsor. Residents 
bring their smokers and camp out the night before.  

 
Wording From Last Year: 
Tomorrow is our Bbq Cookoff and Kickball Tournament! The first game starts at 9:00 AM and 
the first BBQ turn in is at 11:00 AM.

108 
 
Porters: Jani King has a porter service that we can hire for additional trash pickup. Highpointe 
management has the porter come out periodically to pick up trash to help mitigate debris from 
construction and neighborhood use. Porters are also scheduled for each Food Truck Friday and social 
events. 
 
Cleaning Supplies: Jani King orders cleaning supplies and bills back the community. Janitor Warehouse 
delivers the supplies directly to the center and will leave a receipt. Please store receipt in filling cabinet 
along with the others for record. Highpointe management will order additional cleaning supplies for 
amenity center reservations and office use.  
 
Cleaning Requests/Issues: Please contact the operations manager or owner if there’s noticeable issues 
with the cleaning or special cleaning requests needs to take place.  
 
Spray Sensor: Jani King is responsible for replacing all batteries and fragrance in the spray sensors. You 
will notice if the batteries are out if the light blinks red. Spray sensors are throughout the amenity center, 
amenity center bathrooms, pool bathrooms and gym bathrooms.  
 
6.5 SOUTH WEST MAITENANCE – SMALL REPAIRS 
South West Maintenance handles small repairs only. Please have all repairs over $500 to be approved by 
board and have at least 2 other bids for price comparison (unless it is urgent). A few examples of work 
submitted to SWM is: 
 

o Light bulb replacement 
o Amenity bulk trash removal 
o Changing basketball or soccer nets 
o Power washing 
o Moving furniture 
o Cleaning light fixtures 
o Hanging/installing amenity signs 
o Leaking fixture 
o Etc. 

 
Invoices: Please make sure the invoices sent in by SWM are tax free and the description on the 
invoice accurately reflects the work done.  
  

6.6 LIFEGUARD4HIRE – POOL CLEANING AND MONITORING 
 
Customer Service Contact: Katie Radke

items shall be covered or weighted 
down to prevent wind from blowing such materials off the construction site. 

The dumping, burying or burning of trash is not permitted anywhere in Highpointe. 

It is imperative that, when moving heavy equipment around, precautions be taken to prevent 
damage to pavement, curbs, and vegetation. Crawler tractors are not to be operated on paved or 
concrete surfaces. Mud, dirt and other construction debris that is tracked off site shall be cleaned 
on a daily basis. 

Sanitary Facilities 

A temporary sanitary facility ( chemical toilet) shall be provided and maintained for the use of 
construction workers. 

Construction Parking 

Construction crews shall not park on, or otherwise use, other Lots. No construction vehicle will 
be permitted to leak oil or otherwise damage or deface any street located within the community. 

Schedule of Fines 

Periodic inspections by a representative of the Master Architectural Control Committee 
may take place in order to identify non-complying construction activities. Listed below is 
the schedule of fines which may be assessed.

Duration of Construction 

A residence shall be complete and available for occupancy on or before eighteen (18) months

Highpointe Property Owners Association 

Curbside Residential Refuse Collection 

Contractor will provide each residence with one (1) 96-gallon roll out cart for collection service 
for Refuse one (1) time per week. Refuse collection is limited to the contents of the cart plus two 
(2) additional bags or bundles. 

Curbside Single Stream Recycling 

Contractor will provide each residence with one (1) 96-gallon roll out cart for collection service 
for recycled materials one (1) time per week. Recycled material is limited to the contents of the 
cart only. 

Curbside Bulky/Pickup 

Contractor shall provide two (2) curbside bulky or brush waste collection(s) per year to each 

Residential Customer. Residential Customer must call the Contractor to schedule their bulky or 

brush collections. Additional collections would be available at a cost determined by the 

Contractor. 

The Contractor is not required to pick up refrigerators unless written evidence is posted in clear 

view of refrigerator and all other applicable appliances that all Freon has been removed by a 

certified refrigeration technician. 

Each collection will restrict the volume collected to three {3) cubic yards per Residential Unit. 

Yard waste must be bundled and tied and cut into four (4) foot lengths not to exceed 40 pounds 

per bundle.

• Residents might ask why Spectrum (formally Time Warner) is the only internet provider 

out at Highpointe. Please let them know that during the period of laying infrastructure 
that the developer set up a marking agreement with the company to exclusively run lines. 
Other internet providers are not prohibited to run lines; however, it would be extremely 
costly for them to do so now so they will decline setting up service in Highpointe.  

 
4.3 TRASH & BULK PICKUPS 
 

Trash day is Monday. Recycling is every other Monday. Since Highpointe is a private community, the 
POA has a contract in place for TDS to service all Highpointe residents. Even with this contract, residents 
are solely responsible to set up trash services. Trash services are NOT included in Highpointe dues. 
Residents are NOT allowed to use an alternative trash service. Trash cans may only be out the day of 



Highpointe POA Operations Manual 

 

Page | 10  CONFIDENTIAL TO FIRSTSERVICE RESIDENTIAL 

 

service (please be lenient on trash cans out Sunday evening and Tuesday morning when doing 
inspections).  

Each HP resident household may order from Texas Disposal Systems Inc (TDS) two FREE curbside 
bulky or brush waste collections per year. They can contact TDS (800) 375-8375 to schedule a collection.

I. Term 

 
The Agreement shall commence on April 1, 2023 for an initial term of one year 
(hereinafter the “Initial Period”) and will continue after the initial term for subsequent 
periods of one year each unless terminated by either party upon written notice to the 
other, given at least three months prior to the end of the Initial Period, or three months 
prior to any subsequent date, after the end of the initial period.  This agreement may not 
be terminated without cause, nor may it be terminated prior to the extension of cure 
periods of not less than fifteen business days by the party seeking termination. 
 

II. Services 
 
FITNESS MACHINE TECHNICIANS OF TEXAS will provide the following services at 
HIGHPOINTE OF DRIPPING SPRINGS on the stated equipment in Appendix “A”: 
 
A. Provide routine maintenance visits 4 times / year.  All equipment will be adjusted, 

calibrated, lubricated, safety checked, disinfected and where appropriate, “test 
modes” evaluated.  A report of all work done will be emailed/mailed by FITNESS 
MACHINE TECHNICIANS OF TEXAS at the satisfactory completion of the 
maintenance visit. Detailed, but not complete, information on the preventative 
maintenance is noted in Appendix “C”. 
 

 
 
 
 

 
B. Be on call during normal business hours for emergency repair service.  

Emergency visits will be billed at the rates listed in Appendix “B”, unless 
otherwise specified under manufacturer’s warranty.

will be billed as stated in Appendix “B”, unless otherwise specified under

Terms used but not defined herein shall be given those definitions set forth in the First Amended and 
Restated Master Declaration of Covenants. Conditions and Restrictions - Highpointe Residential 
recorded at Vol. 2839, P. 623, Public Records of Hays County, Texas, as amended (the "Declaration"). 

Note: Texas statutes presently render null and void any restriction in the Declaration which prohibits the 
installation of solar devices or energy efficient roofing on a residential lot. The Board and/or the 
architectural approval authority under the Declaration has adopted this policy in lieu of any express 
prohibition against solar devices or energy efficient roofing, or any provision regulating such matters 
which conflict with Texas law. 

A. DEFINITIONS AND GENERAL PROVISIONS 

1. Solar Energy Device Defined. A "Solar Energy Device" means a system or series of 
mechanisms designed primarily to provide heating or cooling or to produce electrical or mechanical 
power by collecting and transferring solar-generated energy. The term includes a mechanical or chemical 
device that has the ability to store solar-generated energy for use in heating or cooling or in the 
production of power. 

2. Energy Efficiency Roofing Defined. As used in this Policy, "Energy Efficiency Roofing" 
means shingles that are designed primarily to: (a) be wind and hail resistant; (b) provide heating and 
cooling efficiencies greater than those provided by customary composite shingles; or ( c) provide solar 
generation capabilities. 

3. Architectural Review Approval Required. Approval by the architectural review authority 
under the Declaration (the "ACC") is required prior to installing a Solar Energy Device or Energy 
Efficient Roofing. The ACC is not responsible for: (i) errors in or omissions in the any application 
submitted to the ACC for approval; (ii) supervising the installation or construction to confirm compliance

documents.content:
first ten years.

OWNER RESPONSIBILITIES
Notification of Leaks 
In the event of a leak through the GAF Roofing Materials, you MUST make sure that GAF is notified directly about the leak, in writing, 
within 30 days by email (preferred) at guaranteeleak@gaf.com or by postal mail to GAF Guarantee Services, 1 Campus Drive, 
Parsippany, NJ 07054, or GAF will have no responsibility for making repairs. NOTE: The roofing contractor is NOT an agent of GAF; 
notice to the roofing contractor is NOT notice to GAF.
By notifying GAF, you authorize GAF to investigate the cause of the leak. If the investigation reveals that the leak is not covered by this 
guarantee, you agree to pay an investigation cost of $500. This guarantee will be cancelled if you fail to pay this cost within 30 days of 
receipt of an invoice for it.

Preventative Maintenance and Repairs
A. You must perform regular inspections and maintenance and keep records of this work. 

B.  To keep this guarantee in effect, you must repair any conditions in the building structure or roofing system that are not covered by this 
guarantee but that GAF concludes may be threatening the integrity of the GAF Roofing Materials. Any such repairs must be performed 
by a GAF-certified roofing contractor. Failure to make timely repairs may jeopardize guarantee coverage.

C.  You may make temporary repairs to minimize damage to the building or its contents in an emergency, at your sole expense. These 
repairs will not result in cancellation of the guarantee as long as they are reasonable and customary and do not result in permanent 
damage to the GAF Roofing Materials.

D.  Any equipment or material that impedes any inspection or repair must be removed at your expense so that GAF can perform inspections  
or repairs.  

EXCLUSIONS FROM COVERAGE
(e.g., items that are not “ordinary wear and tear” or are beyond GAF’s control) 
This guarantee does NOT cover conditions other than leaks.

POA ASSESSMENTS

Currently, the POA assessments are $255/quarterly. Quarterly payments are due on January 1st, April 1st,
July 1st, and October 1st.
 
Payments made after the 15th of the month will be considered late and interest will be applied to your
account.

payment methods

 WHAT ARE MY ASSESSMENTS? 
 

WHAT DO MY ASSESSMENTS PAY FOR?

 
1.  You may pay your Highpointe POA assessment of $255 per quarter online by going to
www.clickpay.com/firstservice or by logging on to your resident portal.
 
2.    You may utilize your banking institution’s online Bill Pay or send in a check. Please use the info below.

Newark, NJ 07101-8060

Chris,

We at Sunscape Landscaping are thrilled to have the opportunity to submit a proposal that will 
help Highpointe HOA elevate the beauty of your property. We know abundant time and effort 
have been spent developing Highpointe HOA, and we appreciate the opportunity to maintain 
and enhance the landscaping for years to come.

With our recommended plan, your landscape will always thrive and look its absolute best. Our 
plan is based on both the specific needs of your community and our years of experience in 
maintaining Central Texas landscapes.

Simply put, our goal is to make your job easier and to be your long-term partner. We place the 
utmost value on providing memorable service, exceptional quality, and frequent 
communication. Our experienced and in-house irrigation, enhancement, detail, and 
maintenance teams can solve almost any landscaping problem that may arise.

Thank you again for this opportunity, and we hope to work with you for years to come!

PURPOSE 

The purpose of this certificate is to give Highpointe, an annual credit of $10,000.00 for any landscape 
enhancement project proposed by Sunscape Landscaping and approved by a Highpointe representative. 
Included enhancement projects include work to be performed by Sunscape Landscaping in order to 
improve the Highpointe HOA property. Excluded services include irrigation projects and subcontracted 
work. 

This certificate is contingent upon the execution of a minimum of a one-year landscape maintenance 
agreement with Sunscape Landscaping. It is not redeemable for cash and is not redeemable in the event 
the client cancels the current landscape maintenance agreement with Sunscape Landscaping.  
Certificate expires after (12) months from the first day of beginning of new agreement and is renewable 
annually in the exact amount barring any changes to existing contract. Upon changes to existing 
agreement, Sunscape Landscaping reserves the right to adjust the amount of the certificate based upon 
new agreement.

ATTACHMENT 11 
HP PROPERTY OWNERS ASSOCIATION, INC. 

XERISCAPING POLICY 

Terms used but not defined herein shall be given those definitions set forth in the First 
Amended and Restated Master Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions -
Highpointe Residential recorded at Vol. 2839, P. 623, Public Records of Hays County, Texas, as 
amended (the "Declaration"). 

Note: Texas statutes presently render null and void any restriction in the Declaration which 
completely prohibits the installation of drought-resistant landscaping or water-conserving turf on 
a residential lot, which is a landscaping procedure known as xeriscaping ("Xeriscaping"). The 
Board of the Association has adopted this policy in lieu of any express prohibition against 
Xeriscaping or any provision regulating such matters which conflict with Texas law. 

A. ARCHITECTURAL REVIEW APPROVAL REQUIRED. 

Approval by the ACC under the Declaration and/or the Architectural Guidelines for Highpointe 
is required prior to installing Xeriscaping. Some Sections within Highpointe may have 
Xeriscaping requirements specific to those particular Sections which are contrary to or in addition 
to the terms and conditions contained herein. Each Owner must review and comply with any and 
all Restrictions applicable to Owner's property. 

No Owners shall install gravel, rocks or cacti that in the aggregate encompass more than 10% of 
such Owner's front yard or more than 30% of such Owner's back yard. The ACC is not 
responsible for: (i) errors or omissions in the application submitted to the Reviewer for approval; 
(ii) supervising installation or construction to confirm compliance with an approved application 
or (iii) the compliance of an approved application with governmental codes and ordinances, state 
and federal laws. 

B. XERISCAPING PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS
