31 CANOPY CONDOMINIUMS 

CONDOMINIUM DECLARATION 



ARTICLE 11 
CONSTRUCTION & USE RESTRICTIONS 

11.1. Variance. The Property is subject to the restrictions contained in this Article 11, 
and subject to the Rules. The Declarant may grant a variance or waiver of a restriction or Rule 
during the Development Period. The Board, with the Declarant' s written consent during the 
Development Period, may grant a variance or waiver of a restriction or Rule on a case-by-case 
basis when unique circumstances dictate, and may limit or condition its grant. To be effective, a 
variance must be in writing and executed by the Declarant and/or a Majority of the Board, as 
applicable. The grant of a variance shall not constitute a waiver or estoppel of the right to deny 
a variance in other circumstances. 

11.2. Declarant Privileges. In connection with the development and marketing of 
Units, Declarant has reserved a number of rights and privileges that are not available to other 
Owners or Residents. Declarant' s exercise of a right or privilege that appears to violate the 
Documents does not constitute waiver or abandonment of the applicable provision of the 
Documents. 

11.3. Association's Right to Promulgate Rules and Amend Community Manual. The 
Association, acting through the Board, is granted the right to adopt, amend, repeal, and enforce 
reasonable Rules, and penalties for infractions thereof, regarding the occupancy, use, 
disposition, maintenance, appearance, and enjoyment of the Property. The Board is further 
granted the right to amend, repeal, and enforce the Community Manual, setting forth therein 
such policies governing the Association as the Board determines. During the Development 
Period, any modification, amendment, or repeal to the Community Manual or the Rules, and 
each new policy or Rule, must be approved in advance and in writing by the Declarant.

12.2.3. Violation Constitutes Default. Failure by the tenant or the tenant's guests 
to comply with the Documents or Applicable Law is deemed to be a default under the 
lease. When the Association notifies an Owner of such violation, the Owner will 
promptly obtain compliance or exercise his rights as a landlord for tenant's breach of 
lease. If the tenant's violation continues or is repeated, and if the Owner is unable, 
unwilling, or unavailable to obtain his tenant's compliance, then the Association has the 
power and right to pursue the remedies of a landlord under the lease or Applicable Law 
for the default, including eviction of the tenant. 

12.2.4. Association as Attorney-in-Fact. Notwithstanding the absence of an 
express provision in the lease agreement for enforcement of the Documents by the 
Association, each Owner appoints the Association as the Owner's attorney-in-fact, with

2. Remodels- Proposed price does not include the installation of any specialty fixtures (e.g. pedestal lavatory, 
whirlpool tub, wall mount faucet, etc.)  Unless otherwise noted in the scope of work.  All owner provided fixtures 
must be on the job site the morning of the scheduled installation day.   

3. Water Services-If there are any water connections located on the main service line. 
4. Underground Utilities-Any underground utilities not marked or which are the owner’s responsibility.  Note:  If 

needed Clarke Kent Plumbing will have the underground utilities, made available to us, marked.  Clarke Kent 
Plumbing is not responsible for any damage to under ground utilities that have not been marked. 

5. Patchwork/Concrete Removal – No patchwork is included in this proposal unless otherwise noted.  Concrete 
will be poured back to ½” – ¼” of original floor level, patch will not match the existing, any concrete thickness 
over 5 inches  

6. Landscaping-Clarke Kent Plumbing is unable to perform any type of landscaping work. 
Additional charges are as follows:  $24.50 per ¼ hour per plumber, $16.00 per ¼ hour per apprentice (if needed), 
Equipment rental charges and additional materials as needed. 
Warranty-All repairs are warranted from the date of completion. Exclusions from warranty: Clarke Kent Plumbing 
does not assume any responsibility for existing warranties, which may be voided as a result of repairs, and/or 
demolition and backfill process.  All warranties may be voided if the foundation is piered, leveled, stabilized, or 
repaired after the plumbing repairs are complete.  Clarke Kent Plumbing does not accept responsibility for any 
services or repairs performed by others not contracted by Clarke Kent Plumbing.  No warranty can be issued for 
any owner supplied materials or fixtures.

16.5. Owner's Liability For Insurance Deductible. If repair or restoration of 
Common Elements is required as a result of an insured loss, the Board may levy an Individual 
Assessment, in the amount of the insurance deductible, against the Owner or Owners who 
would be responsible for the cost of the repair or reconstruction in the absence of insurance. 

ARTICLE 17 
TERMINATION AND CONDEMNATION 

17.1. Association As Trustee. Each Owner hereby irrevocably appoints the 
Association, acting through the Board, as trustee to deal with the Property in the event of 
damage, destruction, obsolescence, condemnation, or termination of all or any part of the 
Property. As trustee, the Association will have full and complete authority, right, and power to

do all things reasonable and necessary to effect the provisions of this Declaration and the Act, 
including, without limitation, the right to receive, administer, and distribute funds, awards, and 
insurance proceeds; to effect the sale of the Property as permitted by this Declaration or by the 
Act; and to make, execute, and deliver any contract, deed, or other instrument with respect to 
the interest of an Owner. 

17.2. Termination. Termination of the terms of this Declaration and the Regime will 
be governed by Section 82.068 of the Act and Section 18.3 below. 

17.3. Condemnation. The Association's response to condemnation of any part of the 
Regime will be governed by Section 82.007 of the Act.

documents.content:
such as Inflation Guard Endorsement, Building Ordinance or Law Endorsement, 
and a Special Condominium Endorsement. 

15.3. Liability Insurance. The Association will maintain a com.m.ercial general 
liability insurance policy over the Comm.on Elements - expressly excluding the liability of each 
Owner and Resident within their Unit - for bodily injury and property damage resulting from 
the operation, maintenance, or use of the Comm.on Elements. If the policy does not contain a 
severability of interest provision, it should contain an endorsement to preclude the insurer's 
denial of an Owner's claim. because of negligent acts of the Association or other Owners.

52949-14 05/22/2014 

52 CANOPY CONDOMINIUMS 

CONDOMINIUM DECLARATION 



15.4. Worker's Compensation. The Association may maintain worker's compensation 
insurance if and to the extent necessary to meet the requirements of Applicable Law or if the 
Board so chooses. 

15.5. Fidelity Coverage. The Association may maintain blanket fidelity coverage for 
any Person who handles or is responsible for funds held or administered by the Association, 
whether or not the Person is paid for his services. The policy should be for an amount that 
exceeds the greater of: (i) the estimated maximum funds, including reserve funds, that will be in 
the Association's custody at any time the policy is in force; or (ii) an amount equal to three (3) 
months of Regular Assessments on all Units. A management agent that handles Association 
funds should be covered for its own fidelity insurance policy with the same coverages; 
however, the Board may waive such a requirement or agree that the Association will pay for a 
manager's fidelity insurance coverage specific to the Association's funds. To the extent the 
Association is required to obtain and maintain Fidelity Coverage for any party, any and all costs 
associated with maintaining Fidelity Coverage shall be a Common Expense.

15.1.2. No Coverage. Even if the Association and the Owner have adequate 
amounts of recommended and required coverages, the Property may experience a loss 
that is not covered by :insurance. In that event, the Association is responsible for 
restoring the Common Elements as a Common Expense, and the Owner is responsible 
for restoring its Unit at such Owner's sole expense. This provision does not apply to the 
deductible portion of a policy. 

15.1.3. Requirements. The cost of :insurance coverages and bonds maintained by 
the Association is a Common Expense. Insurance policies and bonds obtained and 
maintained by the Association must be issued by responsible insurance companies 
authorized to do business in the State of Texas. The Association must be the named 
insured on all policies obtained by the Association. The Association's policies should 
contain the standard mortgage clause naming either the Mortgagee or its servicer 
followed by "its successors and assigns." The loss payee clause should show the 
Association as trustee for each Owner and Mortgagee. Policies of property and general 
liability insurance maintained by the Association must provide that the insurer waives 
its rights to subrogation under the policy against an Owner. The Association's insurance 
policies will not be prejudiced by the act or omission of any Owner or Resident who is 
not under the Association's control. 

15.1.4. Association as Trustee. Each Owner irrevocably appoints the 
Association, acting through its Board, as the Owner's trustee to negotiate, receive, 
administer, and distribute the proceeds of any claim against an insurance policy

14.4. No Waiver. The Association and every Owner has the right to enforce all 
restrictions, conditions, covenants, liens, and charges now or hereafter imposed by the 
Documents. Failure by the Association or by any Owner to enforce a provision of the 
Documents is not a waiver of the right to do so thereafter. 

14.5. Recovery of Costs. The costs of curing or abating a violation are the expense of 
the Owner or other Person responsible for the violation. If legal assistance is obtained to enforce 
any provision of the Documents, or in any legal proceeding (whether or not suit is brought) for 
damages or for the enforcement of the Documents or the restraint of violations of the 
Documents, the prevailing party is entitled to recover from the non-prevailing party all 
reasonable and necessary costs incurred by it in such action, including reasonable attorneys' 
fees. 

ARTICLE 15 
INSURANCE 

15.1. General Provisions. The broad purpose of this Article 15 is to require that the 
Property be insured with the types and amounts of coverage that are customary for similar 
types of properties and that are acceptable to mortgage lenders, guarantors, or insurers that 
finance the purchase or improvement of Units. The Board will make every reasonable effort to 
comply with the requirements of this Article 15.

will not be liable for failure to obtain any coverage required by this Article 15 or for any

11.26. Vehicles; Guest Parking. All vehicles on the Property, whether owned or 
operated by the Residents or their families and guests, are subject to this Section 11.26 and any 
Rules regulating the types, sizes, numbers, conditions, uses, appearances, and locations of 
vehicles on the Property. The Board may prohibit any vehicle from which the Board deems to 
be a nuisance, unsightly, or inappropriate. The Board may prohibit sales, storage, washing, 
repairs, or restorations of vehicles on the Property. Vehicles that transport inflammatory or 
explosive cargo are prohibited from the Property at all times. No vehicle may obstruct the flow 
of traffic, constitute a nuisance, or otherwise create a safety hazard on the Property. The 
Association may affect the removal of any vehicle in violation of this Section 11.26 or the Rules 
without liability to the owner or operator of the vehicle. The General Common Element 
includes a limited number of surface parking spaces (the "Surface Spaces"). The Surface Spaces

13.10. Indemnification. The Association indemnifies every officer, director, and

attorney's fees, reasonably incurred by or imposed on the Leader in connection with any 
threatened or pending action, suit, or proceeding to which the Leader is a party or respondent 
by reason of being or having been a Leader. A Leader is not liable for a mistake of 
judgment. A Leader is liable for his willful misfeasance, malfeasance, misconduct, or bad 
faith. This right to indemnification does not exclude any other rights to which present or 
former Leaders may be entitled. As a Common Expense, the Association may maintain 
general liability and directors' and officers' liability insurance to fund this obligation.

documents.content:
Crossing Condos  

Community Rules Summary 

1. No article may be placed on the exterior or common elements. 

2. No exterior decorations of exterior walls or common elements, except as allowed by the 

Association. 

3. All vehicles must be operational and parked in designated spots.  No washing, repairing, or 

lubricating is allowed.  No trucks (other than pickups which may also have commercial signage), 

trailers, boats, or commercial vehicles are allowed. 

4. We respectfully request that any exterior antennas or satellite dishes be mounted at the rear of 

a unit. 

5. No flammable or explosive materials allowed inside units. 

6. Interior plumbing problems or damages are the responsibility of the owner. 

7. Occupants are to take reasonable care to avoid loud or objectionable noises which disturb 

others. 

8. Animals must not disturb others and may not be kept for breeding purposes.  No more than 2 

animals may be kept, and each is not to weigh more than 30 pounds as an adult.  Exceptions 

must be requested in writing.  Animals must be kept on a leash when walked outside, and 

owners shall clean up after their pets. 

9. Window coverings shall be a neutral off-white color. 

10. No clothing or rugs may be hung outside, and no clotheslines or outdoor drying of clothes. 

11. No “for sale” or “for rent” signs or other signs are permitted. 

12. No power equipment or workshops. 

13. No more than 4 people may regularly occupy a 3-bedroom unit, 3 people in a 2-bedroom unit, 

or 2 people in a 1 bedroom unit. 

14. Patios and balconies must be kept clean and neat, and not used for storage. 

15. No glass in pool area.  Alcohol is allowed in the pool area.  In the pool area children must be 

accompanied by an adult and not allowed to run. 

16. Garbage and trash must be kept screened or out of view of other owners and kept in sealed 

bags or containers until the day of pick-up.

 Solid black or white staining is not an earthtone color typically found in fence
stains.  

 

 

While black would match the exis�ng wrought iron fence, black is a standard
color for that type of iron fence. A privacy fence is a much larger field of color,
which makes color selec�on for it more sensi�ve. The black would be
overpowering.

 

 

 Please select a different color for your proposed project and resubmit for
considera�on.

Trash Can Issues and Unwanted Critters

documents.content:
Crossing Condos  

Community Rules Summary 

1. No article may be placed on the exterior or common elements. 

2. No exterior decorations of exterior walls or common elements, except as allowed by the 

Association. 

3. All vehicles must be operational and parked in designated spots.  No washing, repairing, or 

lubricating is allowed.  No trucks (other than pickups which may also have commercial signage), 

trailers, boats, or commercial vehicles are allowed. 

4. We respectfully request that any exterior antennas or satellite dishes be mounted at the rear of 

a unit. 

5. No flammable or explosive materials allowed inside units. 

6. Interior plumbing problems or damages are the responsibility of the owner. 

7. Occupants are to take reasonable care to avoid loud or objectionable noises which disturb 

others. 

8. Animals must not disturb others and may not be kept for breeding purposes.  No more than 2 

animals may be kept, and each is not to weigh more than 30 pounds as an adult.  Exceptions 

must be requested in writing.  Animals must be kept on a leash when walked outside, and 

owners shall clean up after their pets. 

9. Window coverings shall be a neutral off-white color. 

10. No clothing or rugs may be hung outside, and no clotheslines or outdoor drying of clothes. 

11. No “for sale” or “for rent” signs or other signs are permitted. 

12. No power equipment or workshops. 

13. No more than 4 people may regularly occupy a 3-bedroom unit, 3 people in a 2-bedroom unit, 

or 2 people in a 1 bedroom unit. 

14. Patios and balconies must be kept clean and neat, and not used for storage. 

15. No glass in pool area.  Alcohol is allowed in the pool area.  In the pool area children must be 

accompanied by an adult and not allowed to run. 

16. Garbage and trash must be kept screened or out of view of other owners and kept in sealed 

bags or containers until the day of pick-up.

documents.content:
be considered and action(s) toward resolution will be at the Board's discretion. 

1. The Chandler Creek HOA swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pool.  No lifeguards are on duty.  Children 
under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule is 
strictly enforced. 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion. Please use caution. 

3. All Chandler Creek HOA residents are required to show their pool access pass device and a valid State of Texas ID if 
requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 

4. The access gates can only be opened with your assigned pool access device.  Gates are to remain closed/locked at all 
times.  The Pool Monitors have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access device.  Anyone 
without a pool access device will be asked to retrieve theirs before they will be allowed to enter the pool area.  Under 
no circumstances should the gate(s) be propped open.  There is a $20 replacement fee for lost/defective pool access 
devices. 

5. One household may host up to four (4) pool guests.  All pool guests must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA 
resident who remains at the pool during the guest’s visit. 

6. Chandler Creek homeowners have the authority to always enforce the current pool rules.  Conduct by any person 
deemed to be dangerous, unreasonable, or offensive (including “horseplay”) is not allowed and should be reported to 
the Pool Monitor.  Any individual disciplined repeatedly, or for serious infractions, may lose all pool privileges for the 
rest of the season. 

7. The kiddy pool is limited to children 5 years of age and younger.  Exceptions may be made for older children with injuries 
which would prevent them from safely entering the main pool.  Each child in the kiddy pool must have an adult 
supervisor;

(e) Restrooms trash cans emptied and countertops wiped down.
(f) All furniture must be returned to its original position.

Failure to strictly comply with the cleaning requirements will result in forfeit of security deposit.

Damages: The ROA Member will be held responsible for any damage caused by the member and or their
guests. The breach or violation of any condition set forth herein may result in the loss of the security deposit,
the imposition of liability on the ROA Member, and possible denial of future rentals of the Clubhouse.

Right of Refusal: The Association reserves the right to refuse to rent the facilities for any purpose it deems to
be detrimental to or not in the best interests of its members. It further reserves the right to refuse to rent the
facilities on any dates and at any time it deems inappropriate or inconvenient to residents of La Ventana.

La Ventana Clubhouse Rental Rules, Regulations and Pool Rules 3



La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

● Noise must be kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

documents.content:
thirty (30) minutes 
after lightning and/or thunder has ceased. 

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.  In case of an emergency, call 911.  An emergency call box is located right outside of the front pool gate in the 
courtyard. 

22. Access to the multi-purpose room is by advance reservation only. 

Miscellaneous: 

Restrooms:  The restroom fixtures are sanitized and cleaned by a private janitorial service.  The designated maintenance 
person/company is responsible for cleaning mirrors, counters, stocking hand towels, soap, emptying trashed and cleaning 
the floors and toilets.  Please be mindful of other HOA members by cleaning up after yourself when using the restrooms.  If 
the restroom should require attention, please notify the Pool Monitor on duty or call the current HOA management 
company. 

Penalties for Violation of Pool Rules: 

Depending on upon severity of offense, action taken by the HOA for violation of HOA pool rues may include one or more of 
the following: 

• 1st offense – A written warning is issued (notification of registered homeowner, parent, or guardian, when 
applicable) 

• 2nd offense – A second written warning is issued. 

• 3rd offense – Pool privileges are revoked, and pool card deactivated. 

• Criminal and civil complaints are filed when applicable: 
1. Notification of Sheriff’s Office 
2. Prosecution and/or other legal remedies

CROSSING CONDOS 
c/o PS Property Management Co., Inc. 
P.O. Box 7079 Round Rock, TX 78683 

Phone: 512-251-6122 Fax: 512-251-3470 
Email: miriam@psprop.net www.psprop.net 

 
 
 
Dear Homeowners, 
 
 
 
POOL UPDATE 
 

We would like to thank all of you for your patience as we work on 
getting the pool repairs done.  Your board of directors has secured 
the services of Chrystal Clear to perform the repairs.  Chrystal 
Clear Pools has scheduled to begin resurfacing the pool on 
7/31/17 and estimates the repairs will be completed in 
approximately two weeks however given the age of the pool it 
could take a little longer if other issues arise.  We are truly sorry 
about the inconvenience.   
 

 
 
 

                                                                                                               
 
Trash Can Issues and Unwanted Critters 
 
I would also like to take the opportunity to remind homeowners that trash pick ‐ up is on Mondays.  
Trash needs to be in trash containers with lids to prevent unwanted critters from rummaging through 
trash.  If you do not have a container you can bring your trash bags out on Monday mornings.  Once 
trash has been picked, up trash cans need to be stored out of view.  Non‐adherence to this rule can 
result in receiving fines. 
 
 
Sincerely, 
PS Property Management

documents.content:
ACCEPTABLE ITEMS 
• Bulky items such as stoves, water tanks, 

furniture, washing machines, and dryers. 
• Air conditioners, freezers, and refrigerators 

that are tagged verifying CFC’s have been 
removed by a certified technician  

• Lawn mowers:  Fuel and oil must be 
drained. 

• Bundled brush securely tied together and 
properly prepared ( 4-foot lengths, 4-inch 
diameter or 40 pounds in weight) and 
placed at curbside.  

• Total acceptable volume of bulky items 
and/or bundles is three (3) cubic yards 
measured 3’ x 3’ x 3’. 

 
UNACCEPTABLE ITEMS 

• Gasoline, motor oil, paint, chemicals, and 
similar flammable liquids. 

• Medical waste (including needles and 
syringes), animals or human waste. 

• Tires, batteries, and large pieces of metal 
(car fenders, engines, etc.) 

• Used oil filters or any hazardous or toxic 
waste. 

• CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL AND 
DEMOLITION DEBRIS – i.e. concrete, 
rebar, dirt, sheet rock, rocks, excelsior, 
gypsum board, metal rubber and wood. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

Saturday, December 7, 2019 
 

Cooper Lane Condos and Waste 
Connections will be holding a 

curbside cleanup on  
SATURDAY, December 7, 2019 

 Item(s) at curb no later than: 7:00 a.m. 
 

 
Waste Connections is proud to offer 
this service to current residential 
customers within the community 
limits of Cooper Lane Condos.  
 

A maximum of three (3) cubic yards of 
acceptable residential bulky items will be 
collected. Resident’s bulky items should be 
neatly placed at the curb by 7:00 a.m. on 
the scheduled pick-up.  

 
Note: Items placed at the curb later 
than 7:00 AM and/or exceeds the 3 
cubic yard limit will not be serviced. 
The resident will be responsible for 
arranging for proper disposal of 
anything put out after 7:00 a.m. or 
over the 3 cubic yard limit.  

 
 

NO BULKY WASTE SHOULD BE 
PLACED FOR COLLECTION PRIOR 

TO Friday, December 6th, 2019 
 

 
Questions? 
Contact Waste Connections Customer Service:  
Phone: 512-252-3508

documents.content:
Crossing Condos  

Community Rules Summary 

1. No article may be placed on the exterior or common elements. 

2. No exterior decorations of exterior walls or common elements, except as allowed by the 

Association. 

3. All vehicles must be operational and parked in designated spots.  No washing, repairing, or 

lubricating is allowed.  No trucks (other than pickups which may also have commercial signage), 

trailers, boats, or commercial vehicles are allowed. 

4. We respectfully request that any exterior antennas or satellite dishes be mounted at the rear of 

a unit. 

5. No flammable or explosive materials allowed inside units. 

6. Interior plumbing problems or damages are the responsibility of the owner. 

7. Occupants are to take reasonable care to avoid loud or objectionable noises which disturb 

others. 

8. Animals must not disturb others and may not be kept for breeding purposes.  No more than 2 

animals may be kept, and each is not to weigh more than 30 pounds as an adult.  Exceptions 

must be requested in writing.  Animals must be kept on a leash when walked outside, and 

owners shall clean up after their pets. 

9. Window coverings shall be a neutral off-white color. 

10. No clothing or rugs may be hung outside, and no clotheslines or outdoor drying of clothes. 

11. No “for sale” or “for rent” signs or other signs are permitted. 

12. No power equipment or workshops. 

13. No more than 4 people may regularly occupy a 3-bedroom unit, 3 people in a 2-bedroom unit, 

or 2 people in a 1 bedroom unit. 

14. Patios and balconies must be kept clean and neat, and not used for storage. 

15. No glass in pool area.  Alcohol is allowed in the pool area.  In the pool area children must be 

accompanied by an adult and not allowed to run. 

16. Garbage and trash must be kept screened or out of view of other owners and kept in sealed 

bags or containers until the day of pick-up.

documents.content:
Crossing Condos Repair and Maintenance 

 

When there is any damage caused to a condominium unit by any defect, occurrence, or condition of the 

common elements, or otherwise, for which the Association received insurance proceeds, it shall be the 

responsibility of the Owner to promptly report this to the association Management Office any defect or 

need of repairs which would be the responsibility of the Association.  The Association Management 

Office, as a functionary of the Association, must be notified prior to the engagement into any verbal or 

written contract with any person or contractor for the repair of the premise.  To request maintenance 

repair call the Association Management Office. 

 

The Association Management Office may, in accordance with its fiduciary responsibilities to the Board 

of Directors, may either authorize the repair, or contract the repair with an authorized contractor, 

whichever is more economical and/or timely.  Failure to notify the Association Management Office may 

result in refusal by the Board of Directors to reimburse the Owner. 

 

Table 1: Maintenance and Repair Responsibilities 

Maintenance Item Owner Assoc. Notes 

Address numbers/mounting boards  X  

Concrete sidewalks  X  

Extended decks (repair/replacement 

of wood decks, stairs, supports, 

posts/beans, associated hardware) 

X  Extended decks and walking surface are the 

responsibility of Owners.  If structural repairs 

are needed, the Association retains the right to 
require necessary structural repairs. Failure to 

comply may result in the Association making 

necessary repairs at the Owners expense. 

 

Association is only responsible for painting 

railings and steps during scheduled building 

painting. 

Entry door trim (decorative)    X   

Entry door kick plate X   

Entry door peepholes, doorknobs, 

deadbolts, associated hardware 

X   

Entry door threshold  X

Office, as a functionary of the Association, must be notified prior to the engagement into any verbal or 

written contract with any person or contractor for the repair of the premise.  To request maintenance 

repair call the Association Management Office. 

 

The Association Management Office may, in accordance with its fiduciary responsibilities to the Board 

of Directors, may either authorize the repair, or contract the repair with an authorized contractor, 

whichever is more economical and/or timely.  Failure to notify the Association Management Office may 

result in refusal by the Board of Directors to reimburse the Owner.

documents.content:
THE CROSSING CONDOMINIUM HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATION 
c/o PS Property Management Co., Inc.
PO Box 7079, Round Rock, TX  78683
(512) 251-6122 / Fax (512) 251-3470

info@psprop.net                                    
June 10, 2020
INCREASE IN ASSESSMENTS EFFECTIVE AUGUST 1, 2020
Dear Crossing Condos Owners:
Article 5.3 of the Declaration: The Board, may at any time increase or decrease the assessments if it determines that the Common Expense assessed for any period is insufficient to provide for the continued operation of the community, timely payment of its bills, and the maintenance repair or replacement of the Common Elements for which the Association is responsible.
It was determined at the recent board meeting that the community is currently unable to meet all its monthly obligations.   The Board of Directors, after careful deliberation, determined it would be in the best interest for the fiscal well-being of the community to raise the monthly assessments from $292.00 to $320.00 (an increase of $28.00 per month) effective August 1, 2020
There are many different options to pay your Assessments: 
· Via regular mail: Send check, money order or cashier’s check to address below. Please make necessary adjustments if you currently have bill pay set up via your bank.
· Auto Draft (ACH) program – This is for monthly payments.
             Log onto the Resident Portal @ https://owner.psprop.net  - Select “Make a Payment”                          

· YOUR ACCOUNT MUST BE CURRENT TO SET UP ACH! (If already set up on Auto Draft, the amount will adjust automatically to reflect the new charge)
· SELECT “Auto Draft” and fill in your personal and banking information.    
                         The payments will be debited on the 8th of every month. (Free service)
· Recurring e-Check is also an option for monthly:  You pick the date and amount to be debited each month.

Please make necessary adjustments if you currently have recurring e-check via the resident portal.
·

RENTAL AND LEASING RULES - PREFATORY COMMENTS 

Terms used but not defined in this document will have the meaning subscribed to such 

terms in that certain Avalon Master Covenant recorded in the Official Public Records of Travis 

County, Texas, as amended (the “Master Covenant”); and that certain Avalon Development 

Area Declaration [All Phases] recorded in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, 

as the same may be amended from time to time (the “Declaration”). 

Avalon Master Community, Inc. (the “Association”) was created to administer the terms 

and provisions of the governing documents and enforce the rules, regulations, and restrictive 

covenants for the community and real property subject to the Master Covenant. Unless the 
Master Covenant or applicable law expressly provides otherwise, the Association acts through a 
majority of its Board of Directors (the “Board”). The Association is empowered to enforce the 

covenants, conditions and restrictions of the Master Covenant, Certificate of Formation or 

Articles of Incorporation, Bylaws, Development Area Declarations, and any rules and 

regulations promulgated by the Association pursuant to the Master Covenant and Bylaws, as 

adopted and amended from time to time (collectively, the “Documents”). 

Pursuant to Article 3, Section 3.06 of the Master Covenant, which provides that the Board 

and the Association have the authority to make rules, the Board hereby adopts the following 

rules and regulations (the “Leasing Rules”) relating to the leasing of a Unit or Lot. 

The Board also notes that the Development Area Declarations provide the following 
lease restriction: 

Rentals. Nothing in this Declaration shall prevent the rental of any Lot and the

whirlpool tub, wall mount faucet, etc.)  Unless otherwise noted in the scope of work.  All owner provided fixtures 
must be on the job site the morning of the scheduled installation day.   

3. Water Services-If there are any water connections located on the main service line. 
4. Underground Utilities-Any underground utilities not marked or which are the owner’s responsibility.  Note:  If 

needed Clarke Kent Plumbing will have the underground utilities, made available to us, marked.  Clarke Kent 
Plumbing is not responsible for any damage to under ground utilities that have not been marked. 

5. Patchwork/Concrete Removal – No patchwork is included in this proposal unless otherwise noted.  Concrete 
will be poured back to ½” – ¼” of original floor level, patch will not match the existing, any concrete thickness 
over 5 inches  

6. Landscaping-Clarke Kent Plumbing is unable to perform any type of landscaping work. 
Additional charges are as follows:  $24.50 per ¼ hour per plumber, $16.00 per ¼ hour per apprentice (if needed), 
Equipment rental charges and additional materials as needed. 
Warranty-All repairs are warranted from the date of completion. Exclusions from warranty: Clarke Kent Plumbing 
does not assume any responsibility for existing warranties, which may be voided as a result of repairs, and/or 
demolition and backfill process.  All warranties may be voided if the foundation is piered, leveled, stabilized, or 
repaired after the plumbing repairs are complete.  Clarke Kent Plumbing does not accept responsibility for any 
services or repairs performed by others not contracted by Clarke Kent Plumbing.  No warranty can be issued for 
any owner supplied materials or fixtures. 
Changes to the Scope of Work-Clarke Kent Plumbing will notify the owner if there are to any changes that will 
require Clarke Kent to expend more monies than originally budgeted.  The customer agrees to pay Clarke Kent

THE CROSSING CONDOMINIUM HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATION 
c/o PS Property Management Co., Inc.
PO Box 7079, Round Rock, TX  78683
(512) 251-6122 / Fax (512) 251-3470

info@psprop.net                                    
June 10, 2020
INCREASE IN ASSESSMENTS EFFECTIVE AUGUST 1, 2020
Dear Crossing Condos Owners:
Article 5.3 of the Declaration: The Board, may at any time increase or decrease the assessments if it determines that the Common Expense assessed for any period is insufficient to provide for the continued operation of the community, timely payment of its bills, and the maintenance repair or replacement of the Common Elements for which the Association is responsible.
It was determined at the recent board meeting that the community is currently unable to meet all its monthly obligations.   The Board of Directors, after careful deliberation, determined it would be in the best interest for the fiscal well-being of the community to raise the monthly assessments from $292.00 to $320.00 (an increase of $28.00 per month) effective August 1, 2020
There are many different options to pay your Assessments: 
· Via regular mail: Send check, money order or cashier’s check to address below. Please make necessary adjustments if you currently have bill pay set up via your bank.
· Auto Draft (ACH) program – This is for monthly payments.
             Log onto the Resident Portal @ https://owner.psprop.net  - Select “Make a Payment”                          

· YOUR ACCOUNT MUST BE CURRENT TO SET UP ACH! (If already set up on Auto Draft, the amount will adjust automatically to reflect the new charge)
· SELECT “Auto Draft” and fill in your personal and banking information.    
                         The payments will be debited on the 8th of every month. (Free service)
· Recurring e-Check is also an option for monthly:  You pick the date and amount to be debited each month.

Please make necessary adjustments if you currently have recurring e-check via the resident portal.
·

documents.content:
Crossing Condos  

Community Rules Summary 

1. No article may be placed on the exterior or common elements. 

2. No exterior decorations of exterior walls or common elements, except as allowed by the 

Association. 

3. All vehicles must be operational and parked in designated spots.  No washing, repairing, or 

lubricating is allowed.  No trucks (other than pickups which may also have commercial signage), 

trailers, boats, or commercial vehicles are allowed. 

4. We respectfully request that any exterior antennas or satellite dishes be mounted at the rear of 

a unit. 

5. No flammable or explosive materials allowed inside units. 

6. Interior plumbing problems or damages are the responsibility of the owner. 

7. Occupants are to take reasonable care to avoid loud or objectionable noises which disturb 

others. 

8. Animals must not disturb others and may not be kept for breeding purposes.  No more than 2 

animals may be kept, and each is not to weigh more than 30 pounds as an adult.  Exceptions 

must be requested in writing.  Animals must be kept on a leash when walked outside, and 

owners shall clean up after their pets. 

9. Window coverings shall be a neutral off-white color. 

10. No clothing or rugs may be hung outside, and no clotheslines or outdoor drying of clothes. 

11. No “for sale” or “for rent” signs or other signs are permitted. 

12. No power equipment or workshops. 

13. No more than 4 people may regularly occupy a 3-bedroom unit, 3 people in a 2-bedroom unit, 

or 2 people in a 1 bedroom unit. 

14. Patios and balconies must be kept clean and neat, and not used for storage. 

15. No glass in pool area.  Alcohol is allowed in the pool area.  In the pool area children must be 

accompanied by an adult and not allowed to run. 

16. Garbage and trash must be kept screened or out of view of other owners and kept in sealed 

bags or containers until the day of pick-up.

documents.content:
Crossing Condos Repair and Maintenance 

 

When there is any damage caused to a condominium unit by any defect, occurrence, or condition of the 

common elements, or otherwise, for which the Association received insurance proceeds, it shall be the 

responsibility of the Owner to promptly report this to the association Management Office any defect or 

need of repairs which would be the responsibility of the Association.  The Association Management 

Office, as a functionary of the Association, must be notified prior to the engagement into any verbal or 

written contract with any person or contractor for the repair of the premise.  To request maintenance 

repair call the Association Management Office. 

 

The Association Management Office may, in accordance with its fiduciary responsibilities to the Board 

of Directors, may either authorize the repair, or contract the repair with an authorized contractor, 

whichever is more economical and/or timely.  Failure to notify the Association Management Office may 

result in refusal by the Board of Directors to reimburse the Owner. 

 

Table 1: Maintenance and Repair Responsibilities 

Maintenance Item Owner Assoc. Notes 

Address numbers/mounting boards  X  

Concrete sidewalks  X  

Extended decks (repair/replacement 

of wood decks, stairs, supports, 

posts/beans, associated hardware) 

X  Extended decks and walking surface are the 

responsibility of Owners.  If structural repairs 

are needed, the Association retains the right to 
require necessary structural repairs. Failure to 

comply may result in the Association making 

necessary repairs at the Owners expense. 

 

Association is only responsible for painting 

railings and steps during scheduled building 

painting. 

Entry door trim (decorative)    X   

Entry door kick plate X   

Entry door peepholes, doorknobs, 

deadbolts, associated hardware 

X   

Entry door threshold  X

This proposal expires the sooner of (30) days after the proposal date or the proposed inception date, coverage may not be bound retroactively.  

Coverage and rate indications reflect currently approved and executed forms and factors and may be subject to change effective policy inception. 

Only AmTrust policy forms issued at inception provide coverage, terms and conditions.    

 

Proposal Terms and Conditions (cont.) 
 

 

Please review the detail pages for limits, deductibles, and location information. 

 

In an effort to provide AmTrust customers with a variety of billing options, the below fee structure will be applied to your 

new policy.   

 

This fee structure helps customers to meet payment due dates, ensures that valid and properly funded payments are 

submitted, and provides an incentive for paid-in-full options.   

 

Our fee structure is as follows: 

 

Fee Title Fee Amount Description 
Returned Payment Fee $25 A returned payment fee applied to any returned payment. 
Late Fee $20 Late fee applied if payment not received on or before 

payment due date. 
Installment Fee $15 A “paper” billing fee that is assessed for each mailed 

installment invoice. Excludes down payment and annual 
payment plans. Fee is billed at the account level. 

Reinstatement Fee $50 Fee applied upon reinstatement of a non-payment 
cancellation.

Acceptance or Rejection of Terrorism Insurance Coverage

You are hereby notified that under the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act, as amended, you have a right to purchase
insurance coverage for losses resulting from acts of terrorism. As defined in Section 102(1) of the Act: The term
“act of terrorism” means any act or acts that are certified by the Secretary of the Treasury—in consultation with
the Secretary of Homeland Security, and the Attorney General of the United States—to be an act of terrorism; to
be a violent act or an act that is dangerous to human life, property, or infrastructure; to have resulted in damage
within the United States, or outside the United States in the case of certain air carriers or vessels or the premises
of a United States mission; and to have been committed by an individual or individuals as part of an effort to
coerce the civilian population of the United States or to influence the policy or affect the conduct of the United
States Government by coercion.

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Tuesday, January 11, 2022 via Zoom 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting called to order at 7:05 p.m. 
Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens 
Valerie Phillips 
Ron Nash 
Jeff Lathan 
Brian Ritter 
Butch Miller 
Robert Alfaro 

Additional  
Joel Enderson – ACC 
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 

 
August 2021 Meeting Minutes 
 Motion to accept August Minutes – Jeff Lathan 
 Second by Brian Ritter 
 Motion Approved 

 

December 2021 Meeting Minutes 
Motion to accept December Minutes – Butch Miller 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Hardy Plank – can hardy plank be used on a workshop?  it should only apply to 
portable sheds and accessory buildings but not to include the garage as that falls 
under the deed restrictions with regards to a house.  Ask that an email be sent 
making it clearer to the homeowners.   
 
New Laws -  

- Pool enclosure fences – transparent  
- Security – changes made 

2. Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem – presented the monthly managers report 
Motion to accept Manager’s report – Brian Ritter 
Second by Robert Nash 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

 

3. ACC Report – Joel Enderson 

3 – Projects approved 
0 – Pending Requests 
 

4. Matters Than Come Before the Board – None 
5. Meeting adjourned at 8:10 p.m. 
6. Executive Session adjourned at 8:30 p.m.  

 
Motion to approve the changes made by Connie Heyer to the rules regarding the Texas 
Legislative Session into the Lookout at Brushy Creek Rules and Regulations  
 Voted – 7 yes   Motion to approve  

Meeting Adjourned 8:35 p.m. 

Next meeting Annual Meeting February 15, 2022   7:00 pm     

Recorded and submitted by Valerie Phillips, January 19, 2022

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Annual Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association  
Board Meeting   Tuesday, September 13, 2022 

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

of the bylaws.    

Attorney Credentials 

Niemann & Heyer LLP has been representing POAs and specializing in POA law for more than 20 years.  Our 
lawyers have been instrumental in drafting virtually all POA law in Texas, including the Texas Uniform Condominium 
Act (Property Code Chapter 82) and the Texas Residential Property Owners Protection Act (Property Code Chapter 
209).  Connie Niemann Heyer is a past president of the Austin chapter of the Community Associations Institute, and 
is a founding board member of the Texas Community Association Advocates.   

The Board of Directors hopes this short letter boosts your confidence that the Board is performing their 
role in the Association appropriately, in accordance with our DCCR, & in accordance with Law. All Board 
meetings are open to property owners, and the board welcomes any homeowners that attend. 

Sincerely,  
The Board of Directors & Your Neighbors 
The Lookout at Brushy Creek POA

maintain such facilities in or upon any portion of the Subdivision as in its sole discretion may be necessary or

Section 3.05 Walls and Fences. Walls and fences, if any, must be approved prior to construction by the 
Architectural Control Committee and shall not be closer to front property lines than the front line of the house on 
all Tracts except those that front Brushy Creek Trail. Tracts that front Brushy Creek Trail must rlace the fence 
along the front property line and said fence must be of the smne material <tnd style as the subdivision fence along 
county road 139 and 198. llo\\'cver, a maximum height or any fence shall be six (6) feel. No barbed, smooth. ho!!. 
chicken. chain link or like material/wire fencing is permillcd on the property, except on (5) five acre tracts or lar!!e~·. 
the rear and side lot lines may be fenced with smooth or barbed wire. All mailboxes must be of maso~1ry 
construction and approved by the Architectural Control Committee. 

Section 3.06 Prohibition of Olfensive Activities. No Activity, whether for profit or not, shall be conducted on any 
Tract which is not related to single family residential purposes, unless said activity meets the following criteria: (a) 
no additional exterior sign of activity is present, (b) it is the type of action that usually happens in a home, (c) no 
additional traffic, that would not be there normally, is created, (d) the entity or activity maintains an office or place 
of business elsewhere, and (c) nothing dangerous is present that shouldn't be there. This restriction is waived in 
regard to the customary sales activities required to sell homes in the Subdivision. The discharoe or use of fireanns 
is expressly prohibited.

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Annual Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association  
Board Meeting   Tuesday, September 13, 2022 

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

Internal Use - Confidential 

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Tuesday, January 11, 2022 via Zoom 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting called to order at 7:05 p.m. 
Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens 
Valerie Phillips 
Ron Nash 
Jeff Lathan 
Brian Ritter 
Butch Miller 
Robert Alfaro 

Additional  
Joel Enderson – ACC 
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 

 
August 2021 Meeting Minutes 
 Motion to accept August Minutes – Jeff Lathan 
 Second by Brian Ritter 
 Motion Approved 

 

December 2021 Meeting Minutes 
Motion to accept December Minutes – Butch Miller 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Hardy Plank – can hardy plank be used on a workshop?  it should only apply to 
portable sheds and accessory buildings but not to include the garage as that falls 
under the deed restrictions with regards to a house.  Ask that an email be sent 
making it clearer to the homeowners.   
 
New Laws -  

- Pool enclosure fences – transparent  
- Security – changes made 

2. Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem – presented the monthly managers report 
Motion to accept Manager’s report – Brian Ritter 
Second by Robert Nash 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

 

3. ACC Report – Joel Enderson 

3 – Projects approved 
0 – Pending Requests 
 

4. Matters Than Come Before the Board – None 
5. Meeting adjourned at 8:10 p.m. 
6. Executive Session adjourned at 8:30 p.m.  

 
Motion to approve the changes made by Connie Heyer to the rules regarding the Texas 
Legislative Session into the Lookout at Brushy Creek Rules and Regulations  
 Voted – 7 yes   Motion to approve  

Meeting Adjourned 8:35 p.m. 

Next meeting Annual Meeting February 15, 2022   7:00 pm     

Recorded and submitted by Valerie Phillips, January 19, 2022

documents.content:
in Declaration §8.10.  This is outlined in §4.01 
of the bylaws.    

Attorney Credentials 

Niemann & Heyer LLP has been representing POAs and specializing in POA law for more than 20 years.  Our 
lawyers have been instrumental in drafting virtually all POA law in Texas, including the Texas Uniform Condominium 
Act (Property Code Chapter 82) and the Texas Residential Property Owners Protection Act (Property Code Chapter 
209).  Connie Niemann Heyer is a past president of the Austin chapter of the Community Associations Institute, and 
is a founding board member of the Texas Community Association Advocates.   

The Board of Directors hopes this short letter boosts your confidence that the Board is performing their 
role in the Association appropriately, in accordance with our DCCR, & in accordance with Law. All Board 
meetings are open to property owners, and the board welcomes any homeowners that attend. 

Sincerely,  
The Board of Directors & Your Neighbors 
The Lookout at Brushy Creek POA

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Monday, January 10, 2023 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting could not be called to order due to lack of quorum.   
 
Members Present 

Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan  
Pam Ferrill 

Additional  
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 
Joe Burgess with Coventry Homes, a Representative of Property on Brushy Creek Trail 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Joe Burgess of with Coventry Homes attended the meeting and explain why the exterior of a home being built on 
134 Brushy Creek Trail has not been completed despite the fact owners were granted a six-month extension which 
expired on December 15, 2022.  The Mr. Burgess confirmed the exterior construction would be completed 
before February 28, 2023. He was then informed that after February 28th, the owners would be fine of $100.00 a 
day retroactive back to December 15, 2022 deadline.   Mr. Burgess was asked to inform the owners that they need 
to send, in writing, the confirmation of the Feb. 28th date to the Bushy Creek HOA board.   
 
 

Next Meeting February 13th (Monday) @ 7 p.m. 

Recorded and submitted by Pamela Ferrill, Jan. 11, 2023

documents.content:
in Declaration §8.10.  This is outlined in §4.01 
of the bylaws.    

Attorney Credentials 

Niemann & Heyer LLP has been representing POAs and specializing in POA law for more than 20 years.  Our 
lawyers have been instrumental in drafting virtually all POA law in Texas, including the Texas Uniform Condominium 
Act (Property Code Chapter 82) and the Texas Residential Property Owners Protection Act (Property Code Chapter 
209).  Connie Niemann Heyer is a past president of the Austin chapter of the Community Associations Institute, and 
is a founding board member of the Texas Community Association Advocates.   

The Board of Directors hopes this short letter boosts your confidence that the Board is performing their 
role in the Association appropriately, in accordance with our DCCR, & in accordance with Law. All Board 
meetings are open to property owners, and the board welcomes any homeowners that attend. 

Sincerely,  
The Board of Directors & Your Neighbors 
The Lookout at Brushy Creek POA

Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

IMPROVEMENT REQUEST FORM 
 
Proposed Improvement 
 
Improvement Type: O Home     O Detached Garage     O Accessory Building     O Fence     O Other ____________________ 
 
Briefly describe the proposed improvement:  _____________________________________________________________________ 
 
__________________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
 
Location of improvement:  O Dwelling     O Front of dwelling     O Rear of dwelling      O Side of dwelling     O Roof     O Garage 

 
O Other ____________________________________________________________________________________________ 
 

Who will perform the actual work for this improvement?    O Property Owner          O Contractor 
 
Contractor Name:  _________________________________________ Phone Number: ____________________________ 

 
Construction Start Date: _______________________________ Estimated Completion Date: ____________________________ 
 (Exterior must be complete within 6 months of start of construction) 
Construction Requirements 
1. No construction of any sort may be performed prior to receiving written approval from the ACC. 
2. Upon receiving approval, driveway culverts must be “roughed” in place at the start of construction and must be designed to 

support expected construction traffic.  Refer to Williamson County to permit the proper size culvert pipe for your lot. 
3. Construction shall not commence before 7am and shall end at sunset on all weekdays.  Weekend construction will begin no 

earlier than 8am and end at sunset.  An exception is granted for foundation pours, which may begin earlier and end later.

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Monday, January 10, 2023 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting could not be called to order due to lack of quorum.   
 
Members Present 

Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan  
Pam Ferrill 

Additional  
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 
Joe Burgess with Coventry Homes, a Representative of Property on Brushy Creek Trail 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Joe Burgess of with Coventry Homes attended the meeting and explain why the exterior of a home being built on 
134 Brushy Creek Trail has not been completed despite the fact owners were granted a six-month extension which 
expired on December 15, 2022.  The Mr. Burgess confirmed the exterior construction would be completed 
before February 28, 2023. He was then informed that after February 28th, the owners would be fine of $100.00 a 
day retroactive back to December 15, 2022 deadline.   Mr. Burgess was asked to inform the owners that they need 
to send, in writing, the confirmation of the Feb. 28th date to the Bushy Creek HOA board.   
 
 

Next Meeting February 13th (Monday) @ 7 p.m. 

Recorded and submitted by Pamela Ferrill, Jan. 11, 2023

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Annual Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association  
Board Meeting   Tuesday, September 13, 2022 

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

documents.content:
in Declaration §8.10.  This is outlined in §4.01 
of the bylaws.    

Attorney Credentials 

Niemann & Heyer LLP has been representing POAs and specializing in POA law for more than 20 years.  Our 
lawyers have been instrumental in drafting virtually all POA law in Texas, including the Texas Uniform Condominium 
Act (Property Code Chapter 82) and the Texas Residential Property Owners Protection Act (Property Code Chapter 
209).  Connie Niemann Heyer is a past president of the Austin chapter of the Community Associations Institute, and 
is a founding board member of the Texas Community Association Advocates.   

The Board of Directors hopes this short letter boosts your confidence that the Board is performing their 
role in the Association appropriately, in accordance with our DCCR, & in accordance with Law. All Board 
meetings are open to property owners, and the board welcomes any homeowners that attend. 

Sincerely,  
The Board of Directors & Your Neighbors 
The Lookout at Brushy Creek POA

Internal Use - Confidential 

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Monday, January 10, 2023 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting could not be called to order due to lack of quorum.   
 
Members Present 

Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan  
Pam Ferrill 

Additional  
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 
Joe Burgess with Coventry Homes, a Representative of Property on Brushy Creek Trail 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Joe Burgess of with Coventry Homes attended the meeting and explain why the exterior of a home being built on 
134 Brushy Creek Trail has not been completed despite the fact owners were granted a six-month extension which 
expired on December 15, 2022.  The Mr. Burgess confirmed the exterior construction would be completed 
before February 28, 2023. He was then informed that after February 28th, the owners would be fine of $100.00 a 
day retroactive back to December 15, 2022 deadline.   Mr. Burgess was asked to inform the owners that they need 
to send, in writing, the confirmation of the Feb. 28th date to the Bushy Creek HOA board.   
 
 

Next Meeting February 13th (Monday) @ 7 p.m. 

Recorded and submitted by Pamela Ferrill, Jan. 11, 2023

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Annual Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association  
Board Meeting   Tuesday, September 13, 2022 

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Tuesday, January 11, 2022 via Zoom 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting called to order at 7:05 p.m. 
Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens 
Valerie Phillips 
Ron Nash 
Jeff Lathan 
Brian Ritter 
Butch Miller 
Robert Alfaro 

Additional  
Joel Enderson – ACC 
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 

 
August 2021 Meeting Minutes 
 Motion to accept August Minutes – Jeff Lathan 
 Second by Brian Ritter 
 Motion Approved 

 

December 2021 Meeting Minutes 
Motion to accept December Minutes – Butch Miller 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Hardy Plank – can hardy plank be used on a workshop?  it should only apply to 
portable sheds and accessory buildings but not to include the garage as that falls 
under the deed restrictions with regards to a house.  Ask that an email be sent 
making it clearer to the homeowners.   
 
New Laws -  

- Pool enclosure fences – transparent  
- Security – changes made 

2. Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem – presented the monthly managers report 
Motion to accept Manager’s report – Brian Ritter

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Annual Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association  
Board Meeting   Tuesday, September 13, 2022 

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association Board Meeting 
Monday, January 10, 2023 

 
Regular HOA Board Meeting could not be called to order due to lack of quorum.   
 
Members Present 

Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan  
Pam Ferrill 

Additional  
Rick Zilem – PS Properties 
Joe Burgess with Coventry Homes, a Representative of Property on Brushy Creek Trail 

 
Homeowner Topics 

Joe Burgess of with Coventry Homes attended the meeting and explain why the exterior of a home being built on 
134 Brushy Creek Trail has not been completed despite the fact owners were granted a six-month extension which 
expired on December 15, 2022.  The Mr. Burgess confirmed the exterior construction would be completed 
before February 28, 2023. He was then informed that after February 28th, the owners would be fine of $100.00 a 
day retroactive back to December 15, 2022 deadline.   Mr. Burgess was asked to inform the owners that they need 
to send, in writing, the confirmation of the Feb. 28th date to the Bushy Creek HOA board.   
 
 

Next Meeting February 13th (Monday) @ 7 p.m. 

Recorded and submitted by Pamela Ferrill, Jan. 11, 2023

in Declaration §8.10.  This is outlined in §4.01 
of the bylaws.    

Attorney Credentials 

Niemann & Heyer LLP has been representing POAs and specializing in POA law for more than 20 years.  Our 
lawyers have been instrumental in drafting virtually all POA law in Texas, including the Texas Uniform Condominium 
Act (Property Code Chapter 82) and the Texas Residential Property Owners Protection Act (Property Code Chapter 
209).  Connie Niemann Heyer is a past president of the Austin chapter of the Community Associations Institute, and 
is a founding board member of the Texas Community Association Advocates.   

The Board of Directors hopes this short letter boosts your confidence that the Board is performing their 
role in the Association appropriately, in accordance with our DCCR, & in accordance with Law. All Board 
meetings are open to property owners, and the board welcomes any homeowners that attend. 

Sincerely,  
The Board of Directors & Your Neighbors 
The Lookout at Brushy Creek POA

documents.content:
Internal Use - Confidential 

Annual Lookout at Brushy Creek Property Owners Association  
Board Meeting   Tuesday, September 13, 2022 

New Life Baptist Church  19715 Hodde Lane, Pflugerville  
 
Annual HOA Welcome & Call to Order @ 7:00 PM 
 
It was established that a quorum was present, and the annual meeting would be held as scheduled. 
 
Board Members Present 

Rhonda Kitchens   Valerie Phillips 
Jeff Lathan    Ron Nash 
Butch Miller   Brian Ritter 
Rick Zilem, Community Manager 

 
September 14, 2021 Annual Meeting Minutes 

Motion to accept Annual Meeting minutes – Brian Ritter 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved 

 
Guest Speakers 

 Eric Woods, Hutto ESD Fire Marshall - Spoke on Fire Safety 

Russ Boles, County Commissioner – Discussed CR198 Bridge Repair, SE Loop segments & 
Williamson County Long Range Plan 

  
Annual Manager’s Report 

Rick Zilem presented annual Manager’s/Financial report  
Motion to accept – Mary Peck 
Second by Ron Nash 
Motion Approved   

 
ACC Report – Joel Enderson, Chairman 

       Joel presented a short summary of the actions and issues that the ACC dealt with throughout  
       this year.  It was noted that Joel was stepping down after many years of serving on the board 
       and ACC.  This will leave one open position for the board to fill.   
 
Election of Officers 
      There were four (4) open spots on the Board.  The nominees were Jeff Lathan, Valerie Phillips, 
      Pam Ferrill and Ron Pepper.  Motions to accept nominees by acclimation by Dutch DeHart and 
      Mary Peck. 
 

 
 



 

Internal Use - Confidential 

Homeowners Topics 

      The floor was opened to members to present questions about topics from homeowners. 

  

Meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m. 

Executive Session called at 8:25 p.m. for board member positions: 

Rhonda Kitchens, President   Brian Ritter, Vice President 

Pam Ferrill, Secretary    Robert Alfaro, Treasurer 

Valerie Phillips, Communications  Jeff Lathan, Member at Large

THE LOOKOUT OF BRUSHY CREEK PROPERTY OWNERS MEETING 
OCTOBER 13, 2014 
200 TONKAWA RIDGE 
 

1. Call meeting to order : 
 

2. Roll Call : 
Paul Gray, Bridget Wall , Brad Steadman, Rick Zilem, Sam Henderson, Lori Tidwell 
 
No home owners in attendance. 

 
3. Approval of minutes from annual meeting held 9/8/14 

Approved Brad and Sam. 
   

4. Welcome new board members : Review responsibilities and expectations. 
March meeting to be held at Sam’s  
May meeting to be held at Lori’s 
Lori treasurer to overview financial report that Rick sends out 
Sam Director rules and regulations as needed. 

 
5. Home owner Topics : 

 Variance hearing owners at 104 Sentry Point were not available for the hearing . HOA have read thru all 
correspondence between home owner and PS Properties. 
Vote and decision per board has agreed a consession  will be granted but it will need to be pushed back between 
8” – 36” also voted on a timeline to amend this which will be within 30 days of October 14th 2014. 

 
6. Manager Report : Rick PS PROP 

413 Apache still compliant 
308 Brushy Creek unable to contact 
Rick to look into fines for landscaping issues 
 

 Financial Report  

 Dues collection 

 Annual meeting location secured, re –election candidates 
 

7. Old Business : 
Action Items :  

 Waste water treatment plant still on target. Steve not available 

 Dam area progress still in good condition and fixed per TCEQ 
 

8. New Business : 

 Brad : ACC update 
Variance is only thing will be declined. 

 Inspection Expectations : 
Expectations with inspector need to be set. 

 
9. Adjournment To Executive Session : ( Closed : Board members only ) 

 Collection account and DVR violations 
201 Comanche Circle still in violation of boat sitting on driveway. 
420 Apache still has garage door facing the road still in violation of not having carriage doors, 
I Rules for violations 
Sam questioned rules / clarifications for trailers utility. Flat bed as long as not recreational.
